Walter Brown has purchased one tenement of the big Veasie house on Broad way intending to occupy it. Edwin and his wife are here now. Walter (Jr.) had gone to California. Our cellar has begun to be digged. I expect the house will propel as Eliab says, as soon as warm weather comes. If I could I would send you a boquet. I have a Verbena beautifully in bloom. Rose, Petunia and Daisy budded. We have had a great deal of cold weather during the winter and this month so far- but are

confidently expecting warm weather by and by. We expect Lucy in a week or two. Your assistance is not as present needed about paying her board. We have for long intended to have her here a while to go to school. Samuel has not made an definitive arrangements about business for the coming summer. He will write you about it - house building will take some of his time and attention. He sold his horse, sleigh harness buffalos to a Lincoln man for $124.00. The Pony was slightly lame. Takes pay in hand wood logs. I continue to have "ups and downs" as usual. Have been down since I wrote you last and am coming up now. guess I will coax Samuel to finish this letter. Please continue to write often. It is very good to find a letter at the Office frequently - good bye. 
Affectionately, Sister Lucy
Tuesday Eve March 9th 1852. I do not know as I am indebted to you for a letter but suppose you will pass to my be what I may write if it does make a balance in my favor, I have had many vanities of life this winter, but on the whole nothing very unpleasant. I have my worst trip now to make shall start next Monday and be away some three weeks, do not know just what will be my business next season suppose I can survey some if I wish I am getting about 100 hand wood logs beech, birch, & maple will cost me here about $6 sawing $3, other expenses $1. total $10. the plank will be worth $14 & $15, I lose none of the logs in getting them down it will

be a fair business. There had been considerable excitement here in the Municipal Election. The friends of the Law have been victorious, Sayward to the contrary notwithstanding. Walter Brown candidate for Alderman only defeated temperance man in the City, Uncle Natty was in town to see me last night but Lucy declares that he had his pockets full of  Sheeps Eyes and really plageres her mother all she can. I will say that her mother had better refuse now so as to spare the poor man's feelings. I never not much about but that he would offer himself if he could get up his courage. He is a very bashful man. I suppose he needs a good wife but should think he would find it a very difficult matter to purchase our Sarah is no part of a housekeeper and Samuel is but a man boy, and never will be a man while he lives with his Father; if they should even be such a question in any primer as who was the greatest Meddler? Nathaniel Harlow, would forever be the answer.
S.W. Furber

Lucy & Samuel Bangor, ME. 
March 10
Jonesboro, April 1, 1852

Lucy March 22. Bangor, ME
Jonesboro Ill. April 21. 1852
Bangor March 22, 1852
Dear Brother Isaac
Your last letter was received a few days since - we have been waiting, hoping to receive another letter from Eliab before writing. Perhaps you have heard from him, however, more and oftener than we have. About a week since we received a lot dated as North Hampton Water Cure. He has put himself under the care of Dr. Munde. He wrote himself, but wrote in bed . as usual he expressed himself very indefinitely- did not tell whether he was much worse or not. We feel very anxious about him - more so if possible than we should if we knew he was very sick, and he had told us all about it. We are confidently expecting a letter today from him. He does wrong - so does any one when away from home, and not well, not to tell exactly how he is. I feel very anxious about him. I fear he has been ambitious and studied to hard. I think if he had gone to school with no desire and consequently made no effort to distinguish himself, but merely to pass way the time, so as not to get uneasy as he would certainly very soon do without any employment, it might have been conducive to his health & happiness. That course, however, would probably be a difficult one for him perhaps for any of us.
We feel disappointed as your not coming
$25. I have not mentioned it before. Say nothing unless you think but to have it done.

home this spring, and yet of course would not wish it if it would endanger your health. I do hope that you and Anna can come together. It will be so nice. 
Our Niece Lucy came day before yesterday. We are undecided what school it is best her to. I think she is fully qualified for Mr. Littlefield's, but Eliab is very much opposed to her going there, and so am I. She does not need to learn quibbling at all. She is a dear good girl - a little think, but probably as large as she ever will be. We have some thoughts of sending her to the Broadway private school. I think she may learn much faster what she need to know there. There is one of the lower public schools. I wish you or Anna or Eliab or somebody wise here to advise. Samuel is gone too, so Mother & I must do the best we can all alone. He is on his last trip in the woods. Your letter to Eliab has been received and forwarded.
Spiritual knockings, prevail greatly in Bangor. Dr. Pond has lectured about it. The house was not large enough to contain all who tried to hear him the first time, so he delivered his lecture twice. We understand that at at one Mrs. Johnson's a few evenings since, certain reckless fellows desired to see the devil, whereupon his satanic majesty forthwith appeared in bodily shape among them with a strong smell of brimstone and a tail ten feet long! They, being greatly alarmed sent for the clergy, but just before they arrived

the strange visitation vanished through the wall of the house! This Mrs. Johnson is one of the principal mediums. Two of our nearest neighbors are mediums. Prof. Pond's lectures was "on the sins & danger of consulting familiar spirits." Our cellar is almost digged. 

Our special object of this letter is to introduce to your notice the eldest son (nearly twenty I think, perhaps twenty one) of Mr. Samuel Crosby of Hampden with who we boarded. The substance of the matter is, he wants to be an Engineer, but don't know how to begin. One Mr. Deane of Winthrop teaches Engineering, but asks eight dollars a year tuition and $2 per week board, which makes it rather expensive. William has a natural turn for Mathematics & has paid considerable attention to it. Understands the theory of Surveying well to. He is tall awkward, bashful, green- taught school successfully last winter. Is determined to settle in the western states somewhere. His father wishes to know if you would be willing to take him with you, and teach and help him along as you can. He will pay you what is right for your trouble- he will go right on any time you would wish. If you cannot do then, he would like your advice about the next best course to take to make an engineer of him - whether to send him to that man or not. He would not get much but the theory there probably. Please write as soon as you receive this as the young man is waiting to know what to do with

himself. They feel particularly anxious to have him with a man of good character you know.
You recollect about Samuel's sale of the Brandywine to Capt. Small. He has proved a big rogue - gave a bottomry bond, run the vessel in debt some $500 down to the Bay of Charles Cush Fall. The first Samuel knew it was to be bid off at Castine to pay the bills! So he went down there, settled up as he best could and sold it to another man - loses $500 or more. He has sold the Senator too- notes payable from three months to two years. Made about sixty dollars on that! His navigation don't turn out very smart. I am glad he is fairly rid of them- probably he will do better with some other property. The man Mr. Babcock is very anxious to let him the mill again, or sell him the lease for 3 years. I don't what he will conclude about it.
I suppose Mother will want to write some. Another piece in the last Mother's Magazine signed "L.H.F." Bangor Me. It was honored with a pictur. Samuel bought Memoir of Mary Lyon when at home last - we like it much. good bye- in haste- Sister Lucy. 
P.M. Just rec'v a letter from Eliab - took cold taking the hight of Mt.. Tom, had an affection of the kidneys besides his back trouble- is much better now. He has probably written you about it- likes the treatment and its effects much- in haste- I've been thinking whether we might not sometimes all be very glad if we should have our dear Mother's portrait painted, as she cannot get a good Dag. Mr. Hundy's lowest price is

Lucy Bangor
May 3 1852
Bangor May 3rd 1852
Dear Brother Isaac
Your last letter of Apr 9 to Eliab was received a few days since. We ought and intended to have answered it immediately, or rather to have written immediately after Eliab came home, which was Saturday, the 24th of April.
I expected he would write every day, and therefore neglected to do so myself. I do not, however, feel guilty of great remissness in regard to letter writing. I filed a bundle of letters for Eliab a few days since, and I think these more of mine among them  than from any other two correspondents. But enough of this. Eliab is much better than when he went to Water Cure, and he thinks his health continues to improve daily. He had done into business with Mr. Haskins. He will write you about it. We hardly know from what you have written whether to expect you this spring or not. 
Much as I want to see you, I almost hope you will decide to wait and come with Anne, it will be such a disappointment to her if you do not. However, you know what is best about it.

Eliab seems quite taken up with French and Mathematics. I presume he has made good progress. He has written some real good compositions.  I think. Samuel is away in the woods again. I pleased myself with the thoughts that he had gone his last trip before, but there were about a million of logs that he cold not scale on account of the deep snow, and was therefore obliged to go again. He has taken the mill again. pays a little more than he did last year; as these have been some repairs and he has more wharf room than before. The Mill, together with his house building, will make him a good deal of care. I believe I have written all about Lucy. She is a dear good girl- almost her only lack is speed, and that we can hardly call a fault- rather a natural defect, is it not? She studying Arithmetic, Intellectual Algebra and History besides parsing & composition seeming to be her greatest trail. It is difficult for her either to compose or write. Jane began to attend the Grammar school, but after going a week and getting all her new books, the teacher told her she was hardly qualified - so I teach her at home again.

There is a good deal of religious interest here in all or nearly all the churches. There have been a good many conversations, but these is no noise or excitement. There are a good many meetings - morning evening and day. I can hardly contend myself to be shut up here unable to enjoy any of them. Our church is going on in earnest about building a meeting house. They will probably have considerable assistance from the other churches. The Unitarian church is to be rebuilt, of wood, this summer. Also, I believe, a Roman Catholic Cathedral up on Broadway, and perhaps a chapel for the Seminary. The heater lot above East Marks square is to be graded and beautified, and there is some talk of getting a gas factory going and lighting the streets with gas. If you receive the Courier, which Samuel ordered sent to you, you get all the Bangor news. We take the daily Courier and the Independent. The latter is a most excellent paper. I wish every body could read it. From the Library I have now Carlyle's "past, present and Chartism" also Grace Aguilar's "women of Israel" neither of which I like very much. My health is improved

as it had been for these eighteen months, but I am not very able bodied yet. I get about the house and have been out on the terrace a few times. I am constantly hoping and expecting to be better soon, and yet find myself week after week pretty much in the same condition.
We have had a unusually severe winter both for the cold, and snow and a cold backward spring. The grass is greening some now. The frogs and robins have made their appearance and we hope for gardening weather soon. Mr. Tibbets had the house newly painted and blinds put on this spring. It looks great deal better. Charles went down to the barn one morning not long since and found twelve pretty little pigs - all dead. Their miserable mother had killed them all. Have you received my letter in relation to William Crosby?
We shall be looking for you daily, unless we hear that you decide to wait and come with Anna.
As Eliab's request, I have written to Dr. Munde for advice. I may not follow it when it comes.
Well good bye. Eliab will probably write to send with this. 
Affectionately,
Sister Lucy

Lucy Bangor
May 29. 1852
Bangor May 29. 1852
Dear Brother Isaac,
Your long and big letter of the q-inst. was received a few days since. I was particularly pleased with your ecstatic and eulogistical description of the beautiful balmyness of the oderiferous atmosphere in your part of the world at this delightful season of Spring. I read in the papers about your great thunder storm. Doesn't the delicious, fragrant air that you speak of, make you feel languid and unnerved? if it does. I should much prefer our eastern climate.
At any rate, give me New England for my home. I presume you will say it too - notwithstanding its many disadvantages, it has, on the whole more comforts - both for body and mind, than any other place I know of. I should dearly love to see those noble trees and blooming forests and prairie - so I should all your wonderful things. The "beautiful things that Native Indians" and those ancient mounds & works built by nobody knows who. I have always been greatly interested about those old western mounds and, (I mean walls). I value your last letter particularly much. I did not know that you

could do so well as description! There are one or two particularly fine sentences. I think I can enjoy looking at beautiful scenery, but I have no flowers to describe the "surface of the earth". I believe I have enjoyed the Spring this year more than ever before. We had an unusually long, severe winter, and I have been so long confined in doors, that the Spring air and the greenery seem more invigorating and delightful than ever. Vegetables are just bursting through the ground in our garden fruit trees, lilacs are in bloom. Than just had a darling boquet of wild flowers sent in - how you would love it! Real Milo flowers- soloman's seal, Anemone, Benjamin root, ground rush, Violets and Innocence. I wish I could hand it over to you- how I do love flowers - especially wild ones.   Eliab you have doubtless heard from before now. He is in business with Mr. Haskins, as I think he wrote you - very busy - he thinks his health improving, though his back troubles him considerably now. He does not get a great deal of time to write I judge, as he sits up night so write to the elect lady at East Hampton. If I don't tell you, he will when you come home I suppose

I will merely tell you that her name is Miss Ely and that she is a clergyman's daughter. Such seem particularly interesting my brothers! He has her daguerreotype here. She is quite a demure looking damsel. There has been nothing done as yet about getting a good likeness of our Mother. I feel anxious about it. William Crosby is much pleased with the idea of going with you, but his Father is so much out of health that he cannot go till fall. 

We do not like to be in suspense so long about your coming home - we keep expecting you daily.
The religious interest continues - perhaps increases. There have been thirty conversions, an we hop, in our Society, mostly among the young. A good deal of interest in the girls high school meetings every morning and frequent evening & day meetings. Almeda thinks there is more than usual serriousness at Milo. When she wrote last Mr. Whidden was very sick - was not expected to live. She says he has seemed to enjoy religion for some time. When they last heard from the Californians, they had got to San Francisco - Everett sick - Monroe very sick - not expected to live. 
Samuel is full of care and business, as usual

He went to Old Town every other day for a week, trying to by logs for the mill. It is so dry, the drives do not come down, and lumber is high and scarce. Dea. Thurston did last week - his son, Samuel S. is soon to be married to one of Mrs. Lee's nieces (Sparhawk) at Bucksport. Lidya (there I have spell'd that wrong - how many mistakes of all kinds I have made in this letter) McDonald was married recently. Lucy gets along pretty well her great trial seems to be writing Compositions. I hardly know whether it is best for her to stay another term or not. She has just got nicely begun and I rather think she had better. I am going to get a girl as soon as I can so Mother can go home a while. She hardly know whether to stay or come back. I do not feel willing to have her do the work longer. I think it is too hard for her. She ought to have an easy time - free from care. I shall send Jane to school while I keep a girl. I will try to make a better looking letter next time. I am in haste now - we are making you some shirts against you come home good bye - Affectionately
Lucy

My very Dear Son Isaac - God Bless you and guide you in all your ways - we have been looking for you every day this long time - hope to see you long before this can reach its destination. My health is very good as good as my time in ten years past I think I have got Mary very comfortable with the work, think I could all summer with James help - but perhaps it is not best.I feel as if I ought to be at home. good bye

Sister Nettie
Did one day write to Lucy a few most acceptable and welcome words of love & kindness, for which Lucy is extremely thankful, and earnestly requests that the same good Nettie will favor her with many more messages from time to time as she

finds leisure in opportunity. She also begs that Nettie will whisper in her husband's ear a suggestion that is would be proper for him to transmit some kind of communication to is sister Lucy as often now that he is within thirty of forty miles of her as when he was in far distant Illinois. Furthermore Lucy will clothe Nettie with full power, as a lawful

functionary, to "midge?", and otherwise molest, Miss Rich and any or all other members of the household now convened at Cedar Grove, until such time as they shall see fit to acknowledge past remissness in the matter of correspondence and shall despatch to her one or more well filled sheets of paper.
Wishing Nettie all happiness, as well as success in the above mentioned

endeavors, Lucy remains her loving
sister.
Bangor July 31 1852

Lucy Bangor
July 31 1852
Milo

Lucy Bangor
Aug. 7 1852
Milo
Bangor Aug & - 1852
Dear Sister Nettie
Among other welcome letters from my old home, came yours. I have just finished the second reading of the whole budget -- wish I could have just such an one every mail! I do so want to know every day what you are all about. Dear one! if I was at Milo, and one poor lone individual here at Bangor, what volumes my pen would write to comfort such a disconsolate heart! Don't you believe it would? However, I will cease my complaining for the present and be grateful for this day's favors. I am really glad you enjoy.yourself so well - I feared you would hardly find anything to interest you there. Though home to the rest of us, it was a strange place to you. I am thinking you enjoyed your visit to Brownville quite as well as you would if Mrs. Lee had been at home.

She is do deaf it is very hard talking with her. I want you should ride about a little when you come back to Bangor. 
In regard to "washing", it seems rather hard, truly, to be obliged to submit to such arbitrary decrees; but submission we must all learn, you know, moreover, in some cases and in some places, it seems that "might makes right".  I wish I could have taken a peep at brother Rider's establishment with you better still, I should like a peep at himself!  Am glad raspberries are so abundant. We have bought some several time, but they do not taste like freshly picked berries in the country. besides, they lacked cream!
Thanks for your sisterly efforts in regard to "nudging out letters!"  Hope "his honor" may be more tractable in future. I went to church last sabbath half a day. Hope to go again tomorrow. It did seem good to go into the courts of the house of the Lord, and much with his people again. I carried a shawl for a cushion, and Samuel provided more with a chair to rest any feet on, so

I did not get very tired, though the seats are uncomfortable.
Poor Isaac seems to be left quite in the background about letter writing when there are so many of the "fair sex" round him to to write first. He is in rather a trying situation, truly, but he must not despair.  Tell him I should be highly gratified with an account of the state of the crops, present and prospective, of the progress of haying and the farming interests in general.These is certainly a subject which his female friends will not be likely to touch upon! He can have it all to himself if he is so averse to writing on the same subject with others.
I am weary, and must put away my pen. If you are coming the first of next week, I can hardly expect another letter from you, I suppose. Good bye-
With much love
Lucy

Bangor Aug 31 1852
Very dear brother & sister
It is next morning after you went away, just after breakfast. Before I proceed to farther business I will sit me down and lay a few words to you.
We feel very anxious to hear from you, it was so stormy yesterday. Eliab thinks you must have taken the stage for he was at the wharf half and hour before the boat left and did not see you. He has a pretty hard night with poor Cousin. He went to bed and slept all the forenoon. It was so very rainy that two of Mr. Tibbet's men came in and dined with us. Samuel did not go to the mill all day. At night, who should appear to my astonished view but Mrs. Lee and Mrs. Swazey on their way from Bucksford to Milo. They started this in the rain because Mr. Lee was sick and had written for them. They have just gone in the Corinth stage. I feel quite weary with the

exertion of talking with Mrs. Lee. We did not say anything about it but I do hope you will write from Brunswick. I fear you will be quite sick, Nettie, before you get to you Dunbarton home and not much rest for you there, I am afraid. I shall think very much of you parting with so many dear ones. But a year is not such a very long time. We will hope it may be the will of God to spare us all to meet again then. May He watch over protect and comfort you both, as his own dear children, I much leave now, and finish my letter another time.
Sat. Sept 4 - Mother & Anna came Thursday with Jamie. He and Lucy went home the next day. We are disappoint in not hearing from you before now. I suppose you found no time at Brunswick. Nettie is by this time in her dear old home. I hope her brother has not gone. Mr. Gassener is coming to commence operations monday morning. I do hope

he will give us a good likeness. Anna is very much pleased with her likeness of Nettie. Mother also is exceedingly gratified. I can not tell you how much I prise mine & Thank you for it.
Sabbeth - Samuel, Anne, and Jane have gone to meeting. Mother is enjoying a nap up stairs- getting strength to go to church this afternoon. Eliab is spending the day with Caleb Courier. He was perfectly rational yesterday, but is not considered and of danger as his fever has not turned. Mr. Tibbet's has been discharged. He boards on Harlow St. Eliab had engaged board Mrs. Palmer's. Jane goes to school - got into the school and class where I wished her to be. Samuel had advertised the Maine Farm for sale. Why don't you write to Charles you opinion about his selling his farm? He is more alone than ever, now Almeda had gone, you know - and how will his children get along? But I must not write any

more now. So please let us hear from you very often. My respects and love Nettie to all your friends - if you please. When Samuel and I go to N. Hampshire, perhaps we will go to Dunbarton. I should love to.
good bye -- with much love
Sister Lucy

Lucy Bangor, Me.
Oct 1
Jonesboro 1852
Oct 23
Bangor Oct 1 1852
Dear Brother & Sister
It is an extremely quiet, warm, sunshiny day- such as we enjoy at this season of the year.
We moved last Tuesday, and having got a little over the confusion consequent on such an event, and being too tired and sprawlless to do anything else. I will e'en write you a letter which, by the way, I really intended to do before now, that is might (just here I was interpreted by a ring at the door from"Uncle Natty accompanied by a Mr. Rankin from N.Y. whom he is "chaperoning" about town to get subscribers for the "Christian Poets." Mr. Harlow did the talking - er- er -er!) reach Jonesboro before you did, and welcome you on your arrival: but time would fail to tell of all the labors and hindrances & unexpected company  etc. etc. which have prevented. Anne and I are both nearly

wearied out. I have been obliged to keep in a "horizontal position" much of the time yesterday and today. Shall undoubtedly feel better after a few days of rest and quiet. In additional to our other labors, we felt obliged to invite Mrs. Shepperd (who has left today for Portland). Mrs Webster and Lizzie Doe to tea yesterday, which of course made us some work in preparation etc. Our house is nice and convenient in every part- we enjoy it and I hope are thankful. Eliab boards with us yet. Mother staid about three weeks - we got a pretty good likeness up, though we are hardly satisfied with the expression of the mouth. It is quite large, with a nice plain girl's frame. Don't you wish you could see it? I do. Charles was down this week - he is quite undecided what to do about selling his farm. Mr. John Cutler and wife called here this week. Charles says Almeda looks five years younger than before she was married! I am thinking of little of going to Milo soon with

Samuel. He had gone into partnership with one Sam'l Bradeau in some lumbering operations for this winter, and is going up country to buy oxen and hay.
Mr. B.F. Hathorne died very suddenly this week of congestion of the brain. He wasted on his table sabbath noon & died tuesday evening. I preserved an account of the laying of the corner stone of our church to send you, but I cannot now find it. Among other valuables deposited beneath it was a copy of the Maine law. We have received letters from you from Cleveland & Cincinnati. William Crosby has had no letter yet but says he shall start Tuesday at any rate. I am much obliged, Nettie, for the braid pattern, but am sorry that you should have troubled yourself to think of it, with all your cares and so little time- what a hurrying, confused, sad and happy time you must have had at your Dunbarton home - do please write us particularly all about your home and accommodations at Jonesboro!

Anne and I have made a cunning little Bagatelle since you went away - we intend by and by to make a toilet table and a stiffed barrel chain also to attend, for the space of two or three weeks, vigorously and perseveringly to crayon drawings. If she is not called away, and we are all well, we hope to enjoy this winter finely. I hope Mother will come again by and by. She is going to Brownville soon to stay awhile with "Mrs. Gilman Rider." We understand that all Milo was in tears at her departure, and Brownville received her with smiles & open arms. Brownville village turned out en masse to make bridal calls. Please make due allowances for my extravagant speeches. Anna attended the musical convention a little - was not very well, and could not spare time to go more. My back is very weary & I must rest. Do please remember how much we shall expect frequent letters from you both. In haste &
Affectionately, sister Lucy

Lucy - Bangor Oct 31 1852
Duquoin, Nov 13 1852
Bangor Oct. 31. 1852
Dear Sister Nettie
Your darling good letter came safe to hand a day or two since, enclosed in one from Isaac and enclosing the cunning little mat. It is a little beauty- my vase stands on it now- accept my Thanks, both for that and for the letter.
The rest of the people are gone to meeting and I have read till I am weary, so for lack of other employment, I will e'en commence a letter to the far away ones. I have been reading in Flavel's Fountain of Life this afternoon - the chapter on the patience of Christ's death. What a dear good book it is. I have read it all before, but I love to take it up and read a little any time. I was particularly pleased with your letter. Your description of your walks & flowers. I am glad you write in so simple and easy a strain. It seems good and sisterly. How I would love to walk with you some morning - even with the "grunters" for company and look at those huge old trees. I should think
Annie sends love and hopes an answer to her last letter is on the way. It is Mond afternoon - we have made quince preserves apple and cranberry jelly - don't you wish you could taste?

that to a person who had lived at the west or eastern forest growth must look very dwarfish and mean. I wonder that you have not yet received letters from us - we have all written and directed to Jonesboro. I hope you will write very often. I seems to me that if I were in your place, I could write a long letter to somebody every day - so many new and amusing things constantly taking place which would be so interesting to us yankees, - whereas here, it is the same old story day after day. I can tell you that the flowers are all frostbitten and the only boquet we can muster is composed of many colored "autumn leaves" and evergreens - except that in the house we have a monthly pink and a little cactus in bloom. Our garden fence is in the process of making - I have had a fine lot of rosebushes & other shrubs given me to furnish my garden next spring. Two of our nephews - Elbridge and Mills Rider - spent a night here last week. Elbridge is going into the woods for Samuel, and Mills brought him down. I don't recollect whether I told Isaac in my last of Samuel's winter

business. He has commenced lumbering operations, in company with Mr. Bradeau, to the amount of $20000. Most of their men and team have already gone into the woods.

Our meeting house comes on finely. The vestry in nearly completed - we shall occupy that this winter. I have not been to church sine you went away - my back has not been very strong; and since we moved, I have been quite unwell most of the time. Jane goes to school - there is considerable to do, and Anne and I manage to keep ourselves tired most all the time. We have had some good and interesting books lately- "Wide, wide world" for one. I think it is a little darling. We have also read one or two of Scott's novels, two or three days I laid on the lounge sick, and Anne read them loud to me. Evenings we have read aloud Scott's poems. I think I should never tire of reading them. We have had also "Homes and haunts of british poets" Prof. Wilson (Christopher North) Miscellanies and Macauley's Miscellanies - both the last good, good. I have just set Jane to writing a composition by changing into her

her own words the account of the miracle of the loaves and fishes - you would laugh to see her pucker up her mouth. I called down to Mrs. Crosby's at Hampden a week Since - They had not heart a word from William since he started - three weeks before - and began to feel quite alarmed about him - It made his Mother almost sick to have him go - you and Isaac must take good care of him and remind him to write home often. 

            The great theme during the past week. here, as elsewhere I suppose, particularly at the north, has been Daniel Webster's death - The day the news of his death was received, and also the day of his funeral, bells were tolled, flags at half mast, and stores and public houses draped in black. There is an excellent piece in the last Independent, by Mr. Storrs on his death - I hope you will see it. The Rail Road from Bangor to Waterville is under contract. the Unitarian spire "looms up" very tall - will soon be completed. It is time for The folks to come from meeting - I must put away my writing - had no intention of scribbling such an amount of worthless stuff when I began. Do write often both of you. With much love. Sister Lucy.

Lucy -  Bangor Nov 21/52
Du Luoin - Dec 18 - 1852                                                                    Bangor Nov. 21-1852

Dear Sister Nettie

                          It is sabbath afternoon and I am

writing a letter, which I suppose I should not do if I
had a real good Sunday book to read.  I really
intended to buy or borrow one last week, but failed 
to do so.  I hoped to go to church this afternoon, but
the "seven mile (unclear" is on exhibition at the hall
and consequently "my seat" is at present occupied
by the singer Samuel thought I could not sit comfortably 
any where else.
Samuel returned from Milo last night
whether he had been to purchase hay - bringing
with him quite a piece of news.  Our sister Albina has
a "nice fat daughter" weighing nine lbs, six oz!  quite
a bouncer.  book night before last.  I feel in a great
hurry to visit Milo and Brownville - can hardly
wait till sleighing when I go.  I hope to bring Mother
back with me.  I received a dear good letter from 
you and Isaac a few days since, and last night
one arrived for Anna.  You are good.  both of you
to write so often.  Mother had one a day or two since.
I was much pleased with your account of the old
minister's benediction.  I would certainly ask him
to repeat it!  I suppose you are nicely settled at
Du Quoine before this time - I really hope you will find
a more comfortable place there than you have at

Jonesboro.  The cypress you sent in Annie's letter 
is a darling little thing.  Sister Bell sent me some
with a flower, from Minnesota.  By the way Samuel
and I have been elected honorary corresponding
members of a literary society at Cottage Grove.  Communications
to their manuscripts paper (the Phenix)
are solicited!  Shall we attend to it?
Let me transcribe while I think of it a few lines
that I found in "The last days of Pompeii."  It is a part
of            The blind flower girls' song.

             "Buy my flowers,-only I pray,
              The blind girl comes from afar:
              If the earth be as fair as I hear them say.
              These flowers her children are!
              Do they her beauty keep?
              They are fresh from her Cap, I know.
              For I caught them fast asleep
              In her arms an hour ago,
              With the air which is her breath, -
              Her soft and delicate breath,-
              Over them murmuring low:-

On their lips her sweet life lingers yet,
And their cheeks with her tender tears are wet;
For she weeps - that gentle mother weeps
(As morn and night her watch she keeps.
With a yearning heart and a passionate care)
To see the young things grow so fair;-

She weeps - for love she weeps,
And the ? are the tears she weeps
From the well of a Mother's Love"
Don't you think they are darling pretty? Another little bit I saw in yesterday's paper, which struck me. "A man who sees a shovel full of dirt bring forth a lily, should not doubt that a grave full might bring forth an Angel" Jane has done going to school for the present, and Anna and I are expecting a little more leisure. She has not got along near so much in her studies as she would have done to spend two hours a day at home. She is to have a vacation till after Thanksgiving, and then commences studying at home. Samuel brought two splendid turkeys from Milo - the fattest I ever saw - don't you wish you could be invited to dine with us next Thursday? We should be most happy to have you truly. Anne and I have almost given up our intention of drawing for the present at least we find so much to do and to read, there is not time! We have short letters from Almeda occasionally. She seems very happy in her new home. Did I write you or have you heard of the sad accident to Charles' largest colt? He jumped against the houserake and a bend wood tooth an inch squared went into her side just back of the shoulder sixteen inches! They think it can live. How much the poor thing must suffer - have not laid down since it was hurt. Charles valued

her at $125. The meeting house at Milo is almost completed. We expect to occupy the vestry of our new church in two to three weeks. Prof. Shepard says we have worshipped in "unclean places" long enough. I will put in a flower from a little cunning cactus we have in bloom. I am glad you get so many flowers. Perhaps Isaac will be interested to know that Abby Loring had not yet gone to California, nor have we heard from her husband. I pity her very much. Samuel called on Mrs. Hill when at Milo and gave her three dollars. I suppose she's very poor. Everett is well enough so he had gone into the mines. Monroe attends to business though not yet well. Angela thinks of going to N. York.
Mr. Harlow is just moving into his new house opposite Mrs. Blood says Sarah was ruined? by going to South Hadley. Mr. Harlow continues his invitation to us to visit there as vigorously and cordially as ever. I don't know but we had better go in a body & stay a week. He has been very good in sending us apples & plums, but it is almost impossible to prevent having a hearty laugh each time after he goes away. He is a strange, strange man. What a heterogeneous maps of gossip, slander & wickedness I have scribbled off here. Really I will try to do better next time.
Affectionately your sister Lucy
Mary Tower is married.

Lucy Milo Jan 16, 1853
Dequoin, Feb 5, 1853
Milo Jan 16 1853
Dear brother & sister
It is Sabbath day - my ink is poor  and Josie plagues me badly, but for
want of better employment, I will scribble a 
little to you.  I have been in these parts about
a fortnight at Almedas three or four days &
here since.  Anne came up with us staid a 
week and went home with Samuel.  I stay till
he comes from the woods again which will possibly
be in two or three days - when he came from 
Bangor a week since, he brought your letters
telling of Netties narrow escape - I don't wonder
she did not feel like writing about it - I should
thing it would be bad enough to think of it.  I
think the girl deserving of great praise for her
presence of mind. How long before you get over
the fright Nettie?  Did it hurt you except the
burn?  If I were you Isaac, I would nail up
the trap door.  The visitor at Mr. Crosby's a 
few weeks since - William writes as of much pleased
with his situation, says Mr. and Mrs. Moloney
are very kind to him, Eliab started to Boston
the same day that we came up here - so Mother
and Jane were all alone till Anne went home
Mother, Anne and I do have real cosy, quiet

times this winter - It would be pleasant if Samuel 
could be at home more - he probably will be by 
and by - he has a great gray horse of Mr
Bradeen this winter - has had a real
handsome pung made, with a good seat
just as comfortable and handsome as a
sleigh, only larger cost thirty five dollars
so we can ride when we please -  He takes
Charles often for two or three months this winter.
He has fourteen yoke of cattle now - they have been
very much troubled, as have all lumbermen
about getting in supplies, owing to the warm weather
and unforseen ? -  We have a moderate
quantity of snow on the ground, but have had
very mild weather the whole winter.  For their
matter, no winter it all till Jan.  Samuel has
been intending to write to you all about his
affairs long before now - but has been excessively
and immensely busy - you know he
is never burdened with over much leisure -
The mill is running yet, and that with his
up river business gives him little spare time
he says.  He will try to write to you when he
comes out of the woods again.
Thomas Task has charge of The Academy
at Hampden is very much liked - I
should think he might be as Mr Swallow's
successor.  Mr. Humphreys is studying
pung= box sled

law with William Blake at Bangor - a Mr
Butterfield from Farmington is in Foxcroft
Academy.  Almeda thinks of sending Lucy
and her son Miles to Foxcroft in the spring.
Charlie has been with her several weeks going
to school - has taken a fine start learning
to read - is coming home next week - Mr. Rider
and wife contemplate making a visit at Bangor
soon after we return.  Sometime in the winter.
Lucy and Lizzie are going down with Samuel
and back with him - it is quite convenient for
us to go back and forth, as he goes directly by 
Mr. Riders.  Josie juggles me sadly - he and baby
make a big bunch of noise - I don't know how
they get along here when Charles it at home
too -  He is a dear little fellow - I think much
more loving and loveable in his nature than
Josie - something very delicate, noble and
refined - such a sweet tone - I think the
baby will be named Mary.  The prettiest name
in the world if not so very common.  It was a
sad thing for Charles losing his fine colt.  Mr. & Mrs. Sargent
are quite neighbourly - they have the
old Grandma Parsley to board for $1.25 per
week - which will not pay for the food she eats, &
she is very troublesome and uncomfortable
to live with.  The new church was dedicated a 
short time since - It looks very pretty from a

distance - We have had meetings in the vestry of the 
Third church for two sabbaths -  Prof Hitchcock from
Bowdon preached the first sabbath - a splendid
sermon everybody said - Your uncle Nattie
took to himself his fifth wife last week - widow
of Charles Plummer - who lived up on State Street.
The night after the wedding he was serenaded
by fifteen or twenty young men with him trumpets,
piano, kettles.  He is game for everybody
nowadays - Now Nettie guess what I had 
for a new years present!  A beautiful papier
mache portfolio, like Anne's only a little handsomer,
from Mr. Tebbets.  Wasn't it very delicate
and pretty in him?
I will put in a slip of paper which I sent
Charles the other day, to please Isaac.  Though
it has got sadly dirtied - William Mitchel
of Dover, whom Isaac will recollect is coming
to spend a day or two here next week - He is
teaching singing school in Milo & of course
must be invited round to see the folks.  William
Fredrick, the foolish boy, did a few weeks time
also Mr. Finsille.  Eliab will probably be married
in April next - perhaps he will write you 
about it.  I am cold and must stop writing now.
L you are good to write so often, both of you, and
I will try to be gooder than I have been.
With much love to both - Lucy.

Bangor Jan 30 - 1853

Dear brother & sister
I have almost taken up
your custom of writing letters on the sabbath
lately, though in truth I hardly consider
it justifiable in my case, however it may be
in yours.  But somehow on these long, quiet
days when all the rest are a t church, I feel
like talking with dear absent ones.  Samuel
earnestly intended to write to you when at
home last, to answer two of your letters which
I have kept laid away by themselves for
that purpose this long time, but he was
constantly occupied with necessary business
until the last evening, which he had
devote to letter writing, when he was prevented
by company - Mr. and Mrs. Jewett
who came to spend the evening.  They were
here monday evening - he went away tuesday -
another evening of this week was taken
up by a visit from Mr. Charles Everett (recently returned
from California) and his wife Angella, -I tell them
cannot rejoice when the brides groom is gone - He
will tell you a big story about getting his
horse in the mud when he writes.
Good bye.
Lucy

 We expect Mr. Rider and Almeda down this week.  Eliab ought
to write to you - the folks here get home from meeting.  He lies
on the lounge reading loud in his French Bible.  He expects
to be married in April.  We do have darling good times
together this winter only Samuel is not here much of the time

the two misses Raynes who came in to spend 
an evening , besides which we have had five
ceremonious calls during the week - rather
more visits and company than is usual
with us.  I returned from Milo a little
more than a week since - went to meeting 
last sabbath afternoon to hear a most excellent
sermon from our good Prof. Shepherd
on the text "Lord I believe - help thou mine
unbelief."  I do feel that I lose  so many of
his good sermons.  We learn that Hammond
Street people feel quite moved about as
many of their most influential & wealthy 
members leaving them.  Anne wrote you
some of the names I believe.  There have been
several additions recently by profession,
of young persons - fruits of the revival last
spring.  The great topic of conversations for
a few weeks past in the city has been the
marriage of Mr. Harlow.  He has been out
raucously and shamefully insulted by a 
serenade with sleigh bells.  tin trumpets
and by a public clapping and kissing at
a mercantile lecture, - besides which the
most absurd and ridiculous stories that

malicious and witty persons could devise, have been in every body's mouth. As an instance, the story is gravely repeated that when his last wife died, some one came to ask him where a board should be found to lay her out on, to which he replied, "You go into the granary, and go right up stairs, turn to the right, &c. &c. and right up overhead you will find one that I keep on purpose." It is added moreover that the present Mrs. Harlow has burned up the board since she came there! It seems to be conceded on all sides that Uncle Natty can't have another wife, that this one will outlive him, though the High school boys have selected a sixth, I believe - but I have no business to pen down so much idle talk.
The Mercantile Association are having some fine lectures. Dr. Gannett from Boston - Dr. Channing's colleague and successor, lectured last friday evening on conversation - very interesting & good, and again tomorrow on N. Eng. ideas and institutions - How I should love to hear him. Dr. Cheever and Prof. Hitchcock have given

Lucy - Bangor, Jan 30 1853
DuQuoin Feb.1 1853
some very fine lectures. Everett says he has not seen a well day since he arrived at Panama on his way to California - He appears better very much better than ever I saw him before - They appear to me as if they feel nearer and will be more to each other than ever before His ill health and misfortunes may make them both worth more to each other & to the world than they would ever have been without them. I wish you could see him - He appears like a gentleman - he is talkative & intelligent - with a quick, subdued manner, somewhat tinged with sadness.
I believe in my last I forgot to express the admiration I felt for the presence of mind of the damsel who reached you the mop handle or whatever it was, Nettie - Give my love and respects to her, who ever she is! Has your wrist got well yet? Whenever you write, I wish you would just mention William Crosby, as they inquire so frequently if you wrote about him (though they hear from him often) that we want something to say. We have had a most remarkable winter - bright, warm days succeeding each other week after week - but one storm, and that again - since the 28th of Dec. barely snow enough for sleighing.

Bangor Feb 7th 1853

Brother Isaac
A long time I have been proposing
to write to you and to answer some of your interrogations.
You wish to know of my  woods operations, we (Bourdeau & Co.)
have them 4 ox and them 6 ox teams at work around
Millinokett take on townships No 2 Pi> No 1&2 R8  W,E,L, State
about 10 miles S.E from Katahdin 3 of our teams are hauling
norway fir logs, 2 Saplin pine, 1 Old pine, we have a good
chance for putting in many logs.  The month of Jan has been the best
month for logging I ever knew, we have had no snow for 
six weeks, we are now in the midst ( or I rather hope in the latter part)
of a big thaw, which has now lasted some five days, the snow
has all left here.  The streets very muddy and everything looks
bad, but we are looking for a change toknight on the strength of
the Morn's influence, is that wise or foolish?  I had quite an affair
in getting into the woods a few trips since.  I was going over a peice
of meadow an arm of Umbagog Lake which was flowed
when the Lake froze up.  afterword the water fell some two feet and
this was left on the ground except upon a small spring brook
came into the meadow over which the ice grew rotten and broke
under my horse and let him into the brook when there was ten
inches of water and ten feet of mud so soft that my colt sunk,
down over his back, I went into the woods found a sled and
broke up the ice and jumped my colt ashore some 2 or 3 rods it was
a much worse place, to get into than the Lake would have been.

 a course in Salem, Chelsea, Foxcroft.  How I wanted to go and
hear it, but I solace myself instead by writing a bit to you - you are 
both very good to write so please continue - to close
mothers bookmark is a perfect beauty.  I never seen
one so handsome.  She will write soon.  Lizzie is spending
a few days here.  I must not write longer tonight.  With much love.
Sister Lucy.  Remember me to William Crosby.

I usually go from home each alternate week about Tuesday and get home about next week Thursday. I go by Mrs. Riders and Widdow Philbrooks it is 80 miles from her to my camps, I drive a horse and pung this winter a very comfortable affair The prices of all produce continue high. hay $18. at Milo, beans 2.00 corn $1.00, pork $25 flour $6, lard 14 cts butter 20 cts. labor is very high when we have usually paid $15 we are paying 18 to 20 lumber is also looking up and I think will overlook every thing else in this market The coming season], people are putting on very high heeled boots, they will probably get so high that a little jostle may upset them.
You have made some enquiring about the cost & expense of running a steam mill. of the cost I cannot tell, as I have never made any calculations, to run my mill or rather engine 2 saws & one machine it costs about $2.75 per day. I can saw of boards about 7000 ft per 12 hours and 5 am shingles on 7 laths, I have paid this year $1.17 1/2 per thousand feet for having my lumber sawed besides running the engine. I have sawed mostly my own logs/ have sawed about 300,000 ft by the thousand at 2 3/8$) I paid $1260. for the mill and have made out of the operation about $2200. logs are taken at the Old Town boom sawed by water and run here for about $2.50 per ?whether money can be made by it I do not know but presume they can, the advantages of the steam mill are that you can saw at all times of month and saw small lots of lumber to order at paying prices, The steamboat folks are preparing for the accommodation of the public next summer fares will probably be very low. petitions are now in circulation for five new boats, one of half a million - also for

for a steam ferry across the Penobscot at the present ferry
and for a plank road to Frankfort, it is supposed
that the River Rail Road to Old Town will be given 
up. Mr Aiken the man to put it through (as we say) died
in New York, a few days since of a disease of the heart.
The people of the Watermill him all hard at work to
get their subscription up in a million, before commencing
which they hope to be able to do by spring.  The E.N.A.R
moves slow waiting for Uncle Sams land in the West
to given to the States for their benefit.  how long?
Eliab's yet been - Almeda and Mr Rider are caught
here on a visit am intending to go home tomorrow if the
weather will permit, the folks are getting tired and 
I must stop Good night much love to Nettie
glad she did not get quite drowned, hope you both
will live a long time and be very happy as I am
sure you will be.
S. W. Furber
Feb. 10
Samuel has made out quite a letter - I am
myself truly obliged to him, and presume you will
be as much so, as what he has written is just
what I could not so well tell you.  If you could
know how very much his time is occupied, I am
sure you would not blame him for not writing
oftener.  The warm weather and lack of snow has
added much to his labors this winter.  The ground

Samuel & Lucy - Bangor, Feb 7, 1853
Du Quoin Feb 19, 1853
is now entirely bare though it is pretty cold and has
just begun to snow a little - we may have quite a 
little winter yet - Almeda came down with Samuel
a week ago yesterday, just as the thaw was coming
on - Mr. Rider came in the rain Saturday, thinking
of course it would come cold by monday when he
intended to go home - but, after waiting till tuesday
he was obliged to take a waggon as far as Bradford,
where he waited for Almeda who took stage next
day yesterday in company with Samuel.  From Bradford they
went on runners.  Samuel could not take his own
house on account of the travelling, but felt obliged
to go, fearing that his teams would not get in to the woods from
Brownville - but they were all nicely off when he got there
so he took stage again this morning, and popped in
upon us quite unexpectedly tonight - stopped about
ten minutes in the house, then off down street to load
some teams to go as far as Bradford tomorrow - Has
since been home, eaten a "hasty plate" of clam soup,
and gone with Mother, Annie, Lizzie even & Eliab to
hear a lecture on reading by Prof. Shepard - tickets -
25 cts - for help the ladies furnish our new Church.  It
is an old lecture said to be (Thought by himself I understand)
The best of all his performances - has been delivered as one of

Voices of Nature is totally different from Cheeves lecture - not so wordy.

Lucy & Mother Bangor March 26' 53
Du Quoin Ill.  Bangor Mar. 26 -1853. 
Very dear Brother & Sister I have received one letter from each of you since writing to you, but for nearly a fortnight my head has troubled me very much, so - that until today, I have hardly felt able to write at all -  It is is quite unusual for me to have any difficulty with my head. So I felt inclined to be 
the more careful. My eyes have felt as if they would turn crossed if I used them much - From a strong sense of duty, I did write a letter to Lucy Searles one day, fearing she might be sad and homesick, away among strangers for the first time - I think I wrote you that she was at Foxcroft. We have not heard a word from her = do not know what she is studying nor anything about her except that she boards at Col. Paul's for $1.75 per week - I recollect one long and rather green Mr. Paul with long hair which he confined back with side combs, and a pale faced, not remarkably bright Miss Paul who used to attend the Academy, I suppose from that family. If you and Nettie can spare the time, I wish you would write to Lucy It would comfort her much and might benefit her especially - You know she is very bashful

and reserved - almost painfully so. Mother has 
spoken of Margaret - I want very much to see 
her - have not for many weeks - the travelling 
is and has been excessively bad between here 
and Hampden, and for that matter all about here. 
We have had very little cold weather and 
snow this winter and a great deal of mud and rainy, soft weather. Margaret has had a very
ill turn lately - Seems very weak and languid
no appetite, some cough and a troublesome 
bronchial difficulty, if not already seated 
on her lungs - Her parents feel anxious about her 
but perhaps you had better not worry William 
about it, unless his folks write to him. They feel deeply anxious about him. Mr. Crosly was distressed 
and undecided about his state for a 
great many years, partly owing he thinks to the 
state of his health, occasioning, as you know, 
at times, great depression of Spirits - He is very
fearful that William may get into the same way. 
Eliab has just been in - seems in fine spirits, 
most too much elated, Mother says - is going to 
Boston Monday - expects to be married the sixth of April, 
take a journey of a week or fortnights 
in N.Y. and round about with Maria & then to 
Bangor. He has laid out pretty largely in the way 
of clothing and wedding fixings - has engaged 
two rooms and furnished one at Mr. Palmer's

on State St. - the house that Dr. George Rich formerly
occupied - He does not furnish his parlor 
till Maria is here to counsel and assist - He has 
not yet learned the exact amount of damage to 
his vessels - says he may be brought to a great 
financial crisis by and by! If he only has his 
health, I do not fear but he will get along not withstanding 
these losses, and he seems very much better 
than a fortnight since - his cough has entirely left him - we did feel quite anxious for a few 
days, and I Think he was alarmed about himself.            
Samuel has gone into the woods for the last 
time this winter - to be gone ten "great long days"
Nettie. I think you and I ought to enjoy a good 
deal in our husbands when they are at home, we 
are obliged to be separated so much - I am very, very 
glad to know that you are so happy in each other. 
It seems so easy for husband and wife to be 
happy together, and it must be so dreadful not

to live in harmony. I think our being happily mated 

is one of the blessings we ought to be most especially 
thankful for. I hope Eliab will realize all 
and more then all the happiness he anticipate. He is so 
sensitive that if all is not right he will suffer more 
than some would. I am both desiring and dreading 
to see the new sister - I wish she could pop in unexpectedly 
as you did, Nettie. We are expecting Theodore and his wife from Minnesota early in the

summer to make us a visit of some weeks - Anna 
and Elizabeth Doe are really talking seriously 
of commencing a school in Chicago early in the Summer or before - Anna has been here with us so 
long, I hardly feel as if we could spare her to go 
away again, especially to go so far. Matters may 
turn so that she will not go. Isaac you must take 
care of yourself as the warm weather comes on and 
not let a press of business lead you to neglect 
your own health and comfort - I am glad you 
have one with you to help take care of you, and 
you must allow her to have a proper degree 
of influence over you. I don't wonder that a person 
I thoughts should wander in church where the 
congregation were dressed in the grotesque 
& motley habiliments which Nettie describes. 
Lizzie Doe says it was just so where she was 
in Illinois. My sheet is nearly full, and my 
eyes warn me that it is time to rest - Thank you much for writing so often and particularly 
please continue to do so - with much love Sister Lucy
I rec'd your letter on business to Eliab a few days since - he has read it - says he has rec'd no bill - he has probably written you about it.

March 26th 1853
My Dear Children
          The girls are going to write to you & I will just tell you how much I love you I want to see you & thank much very much for your good letters

It is such a blessing thing to know from you, where you are and what you are doing, & thinking, & feeling when you are away off there - we are all in about in our usual health now tho' Lucy has a cold & has been rather more unwell than usual had a very Severe head ache a few Days ------- And Eliab has had a severe cold which affects his lungs we were quite alarm'd about him & he was about himself I think -----

           I went over to his boarding place - I thought he would have a lung fever got him home here and sent for Dr. Mc Ruen he examined his lungs and

( side note in between the lines ca M'J it Catarrh of the lungs thought he could help him & did)

gave him a Dose of Calomel which did help him immediately and essentially that was last week Thursday he is now about his work & calls himself well
           He is going to Mass next monday ------ to be married April 6th and take a journey to Hartford and to visit Marias friends in N. York State
           I have lately made a visit of three days at Milo found the folks all well getting along about as usual I had lately had a good letter from you for which they seem'd very grateful hope they'll answer it soon
           Samuel has gone into the woods for the last time this winter I suppose --- he carried with him $2000, to pay his men

Mr. Crosby was in here yesterday he feels very anxious about William fears that he has a constitutional tendency to melancholy rather fears his being talk'd to and discouraged to much I hope William feel better ere now if he will just look away from Self entirely and contemplate the love the goodness & mercy of God it seems as if he cannot but have joy - joy unspeakable --- Tis giving way to the adversary to let his mind dwell so much on his own demerits --- I should think from what his Mother said of his letters that he was a great deal too desponding and & accusing himself --- Margarets health is very poor I dont think she will ever See Illinois I fear she will not live many months

        Anna & Lizzie Doe expect to go to Chicago Some time between now and the last of May it may be in a few weeks - She is just going down Town and thinks she cannot write today -----& Lucy's head is hardly well enough for her to write much today
         The people in Milo have got reconnected about their meeting house the Calvinist Baptists now own one half and the Freewill Baptist the other with an agreement that they shall each occupy by mutual consent - which has the effect to exclude the Universalists the determination on the part of the Calvinist baptists to prevent the Universalists having any control of it caus'd the difficulty  ---- The Taxes in Milo are very exceedingly high I wish Charles was well out of Milo and it in a better place ----- I hope you can come home next summer How we shall want to when you your new Sister & the little Mary, Charles's baby - & O how I shall & do want to see you my Dear children -- god bless you & keep you in the way

Samuel & Lucy 
Bangor Apr 12 -'53
Ins'd DuQuoin May 16 -

                                                                                                                                                        Bangor April 12th 1853
          Brother Isaac
                                Your letter of March 26 was rec'd yesterday am glad to hear of your continued good health and prosperity --- also of your domestic happiness, but you just wait about five years and you will then probably say that you were not wise in thinking yourselves as happy as any other people when you were enjoying your first years happiness. You and Nettie really seem to think you are throwing all this in the shade in in the matter of real solid enjoyment. Well I do not wish to quarrell with you about the matter. Go on deceived. 
                                We took our teams out of the woods The 31st of March, got in about 2.700,000 ft which was more than we expected to get when we first went into the woods, about the first of Feb we thought we should get in about 3000000 ft but Feb was a poor month I think we shall make $1000, Each with a good margin for more. I have taken the Brewer Steam mill for another year, have today bo't $3000, worth of logs for saving them I paid $1260. Mill Rent last year, saved about 1,300,000 ft of lumber at an expense of about $2600. my logs cost about $12000, so that I did a business of about $16000, to make my $2200. the Hathorne Steam mill is to be sold at auction the 7th of May by the Administration I think, some of buying it it goes as low as I think it will say about $7000. it is one of the best places for a mill on river and one of the best mills

? bushing of Frankfort was here yesterday wishes much for me to go to Frankfort and buy one half of his mill and go into business with him, at some times before this I should have considered such an offer to be a very first rate chance and it is now but I do not want to go and Mint? I shall be somewhat governed by my inclinations in the matter, 
The money for your mother shall be as you wish Eliab has I suppose lost about $600. on two vessels the past winter but I suppose he now feels rich and I hope that he is really so we expect him home in about one week The ice left the river the 5th inst harbor full of vessels business beginning to be brisk. We go by ships down on the seas people of a fearfull temperament will go only on rails Why do you not quit Engineering and go to lumbering; I have no doubt but that I could make two dollars in the lumbering business in Illinois as often as you can make less than that Engineering and have much less care and perplexity than you have You have no home and never can have one in your business. You are at the mercy of employers. you do well for a season and then for another season perhaps you are compelled to him in the interest of your money the principle being all spent first I think it must be amusing to a Penobscot man to see you Ill-noisans manufacture lumber. Why don't you tell your folks that they do not know anything? But I suppose you think if they know enough to build Rail Roads they must be wise. I suppose so. Folks all abed Good night - Love to Ettie S.W. Furber

(note on left side and top) Margaret is in miserable health- her friends are very anxious about her - some advise her to go West immediately as the only means of restoration but it seems to me she would never return if indeed she lived to get there. We rode down there one day last week.
Dear Sister Nettie 

            Samuel wrote this much last night leaving the sheet for me to fill out. He has really undertaken to retort upon Isaac on various points. Truly, our best wishes for your happiness are that you may enjoy as much as we do and have done. It makes us very glad to think of you as so comfortable and happy.
             How true it is that our outward circumstances and condition how very little to do with our real happiness. I do wish you had a resting place and home of your own - There is great comfort in it - but your case is not near so bad as it might be; the worst of it is Isaac's being gone so much. I can sympathise with you in that, you know; in the winter. Day before yesterday Samuel brought a dear bundle of letters from you and Isaac - each of us one, and some to spare I believe - We Thank you much. I think your singing birds and delicious air and luxurious vegetation must be delightful in the spring, and perhaps the whole year round. Still I cannot for a moment wish to change places with you. If I was well enough I would dearly love to take a journey out there and enjoy it a few days with you. Wouldn't we have a fine horseback ride together? I was on the point of saying their you were highly favored in regard to meetings, Sabbath schools etc. and indeed I suppose you are so, compared with those who have no religious privileges; yet I fear I

should think it is too great a privilege to sit five or six hours in a day listening to a dull preacher! Why don't you try to persuade them to have but one service in a day? Or wouldn't that be right?

               It was a rainy day and Samuel went to the Sewing Circle yester afternoon. They have to have one or two gentlemen there to assist about stuffing and tacking the cushions. It is very hard work - tying the twine - the ladies wrap rags around all their fingers. and Samuel wore the skin off of his. They are really doing a great work - the spine of the church is almost finished - the whole will probably be completed by July. 
              Tell Isaac there was an inquiry meeting at the small vestry in connection with the church prayer meeting last Monday evening, which Mr. Harlow attended. I hardly see what Prof. Shepard could say then. His is a very singular case. Yesterday Samuel engaged some shade trees, and several varieties of fruit trees & shrubbery for our garden. We have very warm pleasant weather. I hope it will continue through next month - We shall do our best to fix Mother off journeying by and by. I should admire to go with her & visit your own dear Dunbarton Hills, but that, I suppose is out of the question, whether she does or not. How I have filled my sheet with nothings! With much love, sister Lucy.

Bangor May 3' 1853
Isaac & Nettie 

     Yesterday was my birthday, and what do you suppose I received for a present, A fine healthy boy weighing 9 lbs who ever rec'd a finer gift? Lucy is quite comfortable this morning. Help us all to be thankful, God is good and mercifull, let him be praised

S.W. Furber

1853
Samuel Bangor  May 3
Du Quoin Ill. May 19 ' 53
{Birth of son}

Samuel. June 1 /53, Bangor
Du Quoin Ill. June 18, 1853
Bangor June 1st 1853
Dear Brother & Sister
We red' letters from Brownville from Anna & Mother last night. Our Dear Lucy A. Searles is gone The Savior has taken her to his Fathers House. One of the finest of Earth has passed away. Gone like a morning cloud, full of light. How happy for us that we can feel from our hearts that she has suffered no loss. hers is gain, infinite gain. She [smudge of ink] with typhus fever soon after comeing home from Foxcroft about two weeks since. the first we knew of her sickness was last week, when Charles was down. Anna went up with him Thursday. Mother went [tear in paper] by stage Monday got to Almedia's just to see her pass away She died Monday Eve at 10 o'clock. How little prepared were we to have her go we have rec'd a number of Good letters from you lately for which accept our hearty thanks. Lucy is as well perhaps as we can expect not able to walk much yet. The boy is doing finely. Eliab started last Thursday for the western part of Penn. to look at some timber land and mill privileges which we think some of purchasing of which I will write you more soon  Much Love
S.W.F.

I.S. Metcalf
De Quoin
Perry Co.
Illinois

Lucy F. Bangor June 12, 1853
Du Quoin, July 5. 1853-
Bangor June 12 - 1853.
It is Sabbath day - bright, warm and still - not a sound, save the occasional buzzing of a fly, to be heard. Samuel and Jane have gone to meeting, Mrs. Griffith is up stairs, baby asleep on the lounge. - just at this juncture master "P.P." woked up and demanded a luncheon, so my pen was laid aside, he is now laid back where he was before, kicking and fisting very energetically, his great eyes gazing about full of wonderment at all the strange things they behold. Now his father has come from meeting has taken him in his cap and they are having quite a conversation together, mostly carried on by the father however, with an occasional "agoo" from baby.  He is six weeks old tomorrow - a darling little fellow. It shall be excuseable I suppose if my first letter is full of baby. He is called quite a "for'ad" baby for his age - holds his head up as strongly as most any body, has coughed loud once, reads people's countenances attentively, looks about him quite intelligently and above all eats most voraciously. He has considerable soft brown hair 
Written up the left side:
Samuel sent Theodore $200. as soon as he heard of the loss of his buildings - was'nt that brotherly?

his eyes are at present a very deep blue - various opinions are expressed as to what color they will eventually be. "In Short" he is the baby and I suppose is thought as much of as most babies are, and perhaps more than will be for his future good. While I was finishing my dinner, Samuel wrote the last sentence, whereupon I will testify that this "wonderfullest baby" is in as much danger of being spoiled by him as by anybody I know of. Seriously I hope we feel thankful for as well as happy in our treasure, but O, the responsibility of training and guiding an immortal mind! How incapable I feel myself for doing my part aright. May Infinite Wisdom direct us that we may train up for Him the little one that God has given us. Your letter to Mother was received yesterday. I thank you much for the few lines of love and congratulations to me especially. But how soon after rejoicing with Eliab and with me in our joy, you are, we all are, called to sympathise (sic) with Almeda in her great sorrow, - and yet, how must joy and thankfullness be mingled with her grief. Dear little Lucy with her pleasant smile and loving heart has gone; but we must rather rejoice then repine, for we cannot doubt that she has gone to her Savoir. I presume that Mother, Anna

or Almeda have written the particulars in regard to her sickness. The text at her funeral was "Is it well with thee - is it well with thy husband - is it well with the child?" Samuel put her death in the paper with the passage, "Blessed are the pure in heart for they shall see God." I think the term "June hearted" would apply to her as well as to any one I know of - It is a very severe blow to Almeda, she has depended so much upon Lucy, since James died - for years she has been a companion for her mother, you know. Mother said Mrs. Rider seemed to feel it as much as if she were our own child. Mother went from here sooner than she intended because of Lucy's sickness. She and Anna will probably stay at Brownville & Milo until the middle of Aug. or thereabouts, and then I hope start together, Mother for Mass. (and N.H. if I can prevail upon her to do so) and Anna to Chicago. I suppose Eliab keeps you advised respecting his affairs. Maria was much pleased with your letter, Nettie. It was darling good - just right - and it was very kind and good of you to write it. Eliab was away when it was rec'd, as Samuel wrote you. She waited his return before answering it - he came day before yesterday

and you will probably hear from them before long. Eliab made no purchase in Pennsylvania. We like Maria better and more day by day - she has been with me a good deal during Eliab's absence. She "knows what's what" perfectly, has everything just so, is a very complete little body (little, I say, for she never weighed more than ninety seven pounds) and withal loving & kind and good, one of the dearly loved sisterhood. I wish you could both be acquainted with her personally. she is a famous hand to take care of Percie - had almost the whole care of her youngest brother when an infant, & understands the whole category of baby talk, baby medicines &c. &c. I am getting along finely - have walked across the room one or more times every day for some days - have not been out to ride yet, but hope to in a few days. I am so glad I do not have to resort to the bottle for the baby as Albina does. This is a strangely jumbled up letter - I cannot tell you how many times I have left it since I began - The season here is unusually forward. The grass & foliage has a brilliancy and freshness which we do not see every year. The little Corydalis you sent, Nettie, is so pretty & so odd - "Dutchman's

buches"  we call the common name - do you? The other I should think was very pretty, but cannot tell so well never having seen the flower. We have a cunning little flower here which we call "forget me not", a specimen of which I will send if I can get one. I will forward the darlings to Anna the first time I write. How we should both love to help you enjoy your 'roses and posies", especially the little prairie flowers. Your suckers are fully equal to the Pennsylvanians Eliab wrote about, the "broad faced dutchman and their broader footed daughters" - Instead of "are you going", they say, "Is it that you be to go?' I cannot help feeling glad that he did not purchase there - if he had done so, perhaps he and Samuel too might some day have moved there, and I do love dear, blessed New England too well ever to wish to leave it.
The new church is nearly completed - It is expected that it will be ready to dedicate the last of this month. All the pews are cushioned alike - fresco painting; said to be very beautiful. I hope to see for myself some day. There
Written across the top, upside down:
I think you, especially, need the sabbath for rest. Do be careful of your health as the hot weather comes on, both of you & write often to your affectionate sister Lucy

is a larger harp painted over the singer's gallery which is so perfect than people can hardly believe it is not finished with wood.
We expect Theodore and Sarah this month. His nice new building, entirely finished, painted & papered from garret to cellar were burnt a few weeks since - This delayed his journey some weeks & may possibly prevent his coming at all - but we hope not as they both need the journey and relaxation for their health. Father has been sick, or at least unable to work for some time, with a sore on his leg - has been at St. Paul some time under the care of a physician there. He thinks of coming East for medical advice if it is not better soon. Mrs. Griffith, whom I hope to be able to keep through the summer, is a married woman about my age - a very capable kind, pious woman - member of Brownville Church - her husband a Welchman  in California. She asks $1.50 per week, but it is better for us to pay that then to have poor help. Samuel keeps a horse and comes home to dinner this summer. If he can spare time, I will get him to fill out this sheet. I don't think it is right, Isaac, for you to have so much sabbath work when you have so much care of business during the week -

Lucy & Samuel
Bangor June 20/53
DuQuoin, July 9, 1853     Bangor June 20 - 1853
And so, dear Nettie, a "birdie" has flown into your next. Very, very glad and thankful am I for you both. Hope it will be as much comfort as our dear one is, and bids fair to be, to us. I suppose it is a black bird as it was "born in Egypt". Is it, Isaac?
We rec'd the letter containing the important tidings Saturday - yesterday my head ached too much to write, and this morning I hasten to scribble my hearty congratulations before any little warbler sends forth his notes demanding attention. The news, making glad all hearts travels to Milo today - Mother is at Brownville spending a few days, but will doubtless hear of it soon - besides, I shall write to her Wednesday - Jane started this morning by stage for Milo - She refused to mind Mrs. Griffith, or be at all governed by her, and we could not get along very well. So she is to stay at Charles' for the present. It is perhaps doubtful whether she even

returns here to live. I am glad to hear that Nettie was so smart. wish I could say the same of myself - though I do not yet despair of being somebody again sometime - I do not feel very strong - cannot walk much, but am gaining - the great, little P.P. weighing 11 1/2 pounds a week ago, takes considerable strength. He is very good nights, which is a great favor. I want very much to hear from Nettie again - how I wish she had Mother or Sister with her. I am sure the people ought to be kind to her. I have been thinking that the little sucker cousin would rejoice in the name of ?! Tom did not once write how you liked our baby's name - He warbles vehemently and I must leave writing to put some thing in his bill-

  Well - Rev. William Govdell preached three times in Bangor yesterday on the state of Turkey & other eastern countries Thirty years since, when he first went there, and the condition of the same countries now, etc. etc. Our church is to be dedicated a week from

next Wednesday. Eliab has made Mother, and Samuel has made me, life members of the Maine Miss Society. I hope Samuel will finish this - In excessive haste Sister Lucy
