       I do not know that I owe you congratulations but you will please to receive them and place them to my account which I presume you will some time remember to balance, Then you will find much comfort as well as care in your young sucker as I presume he is. really we are very glad for you and rejoice with you in your joy Samuel
[blank page with bleed-through from other page's ink]

Bangor July 19, 1853.
Dear Brother & Sister
While the darling sleeps I will try to write a little of a letter to know why we do not have one from you - The last we rec'd was dated the 13th of June, more than a month since - we have been anxiously expecting one for many days. Are you sick Nettie, in the hot weather, and Isaac away, or are you both so glad and happy with your wee one that you cannot send your thoughts away so far as Maine? Hardly to blame if that be the case - "A babe in a house is a well-spring of joy." Anna read all that good chapter two the next sabbath after our little one was given to us. Really we begin to feel anxious about you. I do hope to hear soon, and that you are all well. Am afraid if not actually sick, you are both suffering much from hot weather. I suppose we shall be obliged to do without letters more then we have done, for I know by experience that Nettie cannot find time now to do here part in that respect so well as formerly, and Isaac
written up the left side:
see your baby and you could see mine - is Isaac a good hand to tend babies, Nettie? Or don't he have any time - Samuel is capital I think anybody that loves babies can tend them well - Do please write very soon and tell us his name. I want something else to call him when I tell Percie about him besides Little "Sucker"! In haste and love, much love, good bye Sis Lucy Have you written to Almeda She needs your sympathy

we know has little  leisure more than he will want

the darling.  Have you given him a name yet:
Does he continue "to look like his father & have a

Theodore & Sarah - they are somewhere in Mass
or N.H now.  Last Saturday came a letter from
Chicago saying that the new schoolhouse which
was building for Anna & Lizzie was burnt up,
but they are invited to come on as they intended,
and remain free of expense at Mr. Carpenters'
till another building can be obtained - I am very

to know what she will do.  Lizzie is anxious to

pressing, urgent letters from Mrs. Hopkins
with whom she was associated at Maine, to
[left-hand side]Fanny Fern, everybody says 'tis good. I have not seen it. I do not think of anything more especially interesting. Don't you wish I could?

come immediately and spend a few weeks
with her at Elyria (I believe that is the name)
Ohio.  Was very urgent for her to start the day

What it all means we can none of us imagine,

I don't get much time to write and
when I do scribble so fast, it can hardly be

night and day - I cannot read or write

and wore it to church half of sabbath before
last.  Hope to go part of most every sabbath -
we have got with the new church.  Eliab and
[left-hand side]want to give us the home news. Have you read Shady side? Samuel bought it. It is very good I think. Have you read Fern Leaves

Lucy. Bangor Sept. 8 1853
                                                                                                                                                         Du Quoin, Sept. 20, 1853

                                                                                                                                           Bangor Sept. 8. 1853.

Dear Sister Nettie

                                 I have been trying for many days to find time to write to you in answer to your kind and good letter received the night before Mother and Anna went away. These little "barbarians" will take the time and strength, as you doubtless know as well as I do. By the way I am very sorry that Isaac is so much disappointed in his hopeful son; I can only refer him for consolation to the last line in the Educational chapter of Proverbial Philosophy, which if I mistake not is a favorite book with him. "Expect disappointment, and look for pain; for he is of an evil stock and will grieve thee." Seriously, though I was glad to hear so good an account of the little "filly" - how I do wish I could see him. Wish you had named him for Coigne, for oddity's sake, though I like Mayo well. Mother & Anna, Eliab & Maria left Bangor Thurs. the 25th of Aug. Eliab returned the following Monday. Maria has been visiting her friend in Easthampton - is expected next

[left-hand side and top] oldest daughter. She is much more profitable and agreeable help than Mrs. G. proved to be. Almeda complains that she is so seldom hearing from you. She is very sad. More than I ever saw and lonely since Lissie came away. Do write to her when you can . In haste with much love. sister Lucy.

Saturday. I have had letters from Mother dated at Northfield and from Anna at Elyria.  Both seemed to be enjoying themselves finely. Anna was expecting letters from Chicago which would determine her future course. I wish on making accounts she could spend the winter with you - how pleasant it would be for all of you how much we all enjoyed last winter with her here. Theodore and Sarah started the next day after they left. The first of the week following their departure Mr. Sewall & wife came from Brownville to attend commencement - were here two days - so I was prevented from feeling quite so lonely as I should otherwise have done. The house seemed so empty after all were gone, you cannot think. I attended none of the Commencement exercises except President Hitchcock's address before the Rhetorical society, which was most excellent. Also Wednes.. evening we went to the Alumni meeting at the Seminary, and staid about an hour - much crowded, every body there - supper, speeches, singing etc. etc. was introduced to Rev. Elijah Jones, of Minot, Maine who is the author of the darling little piece "How big was Alexander

Pa?" He is a very witty man, one of the first graduating class - has a son now in the Seminary - said he had been in Milo many years ago. I was particularly interested in Mr. Hitchcock's address because we were just reading his religion of Geology, which Sarah presented to Samuel. He had of course a good deal of Geology intermingled with his address. Since then Mr. Wallace, one of the students, a little Scotchman, recently from the old country brought me his four sermons on the seasons, also full of geology, but very interesting. His ideas on the resurrection are singular - you have probably read them. Mr. Givens, from your place took tea here a few days since & he brought a letter from you. Theodore was acquainted with him & had lived in Minn. - married Mr. Lyford's sister - they did not esteem him very highly. He will probably call here on his way back. Little Lizzie came from Brownville last week - she is attending the Intermediate school - a little wee thing she is for ten years old. Lissie Doe was married in Boston by Mr. Pomroy to Charles

Thaxter, the 2nd instant - rather a sudden affair. They are going to live here. Sarah Furber gave me a pretty copy of Mrs. Sigourney's poems, and got baby a beautiful pap spoon with his name and her own on it. He was four months old last Friday and weighed eighteen pounds a great heavy fellow to handle about. We did intend to have him christened last sabbath but Mr. Shepard was absent - shall carry him as soon as he returns. He is a great frolicker - laughs out loud a good deal - cries for the tea-cup when I have done feeding him with catnip tea! I have got a little willow chaise for him, with two wheels, light and easy. Lissie wheels him about a good deal. Mother charged me to write to you not to draw your baby out doors, or any where except in a very smooth place till he can sit up. She says it injures them to be jolted when lying down. I don't draw mine out doors at all yet. I have written just as fast as I could spring - don't hardly know what I have said & what not. Ought to be making attire for Liz this moment. Mrs. Griffith has gone. I have now Isabel Frost, William Frost

I had just completed my letter when Samuel came to dinner & delighted and surprised me with a nice letter from you Isaac - seemed like good old times - a whole letter from Isaac all to myself! more the less acceptable surely, however, are they when dear Nettie writes a part. As for my remissions in writing, I "have done what I could" I really think. Please to bear in mind that an unremitting severe head ache for nearly three months prevented me from writing, reading or sewing, or taking much comfort in any way. There, my visit to Milo and since then constant company with changing help and care of baby have kept my time & energies and strength hardly taxed. About three weeks since I sent for a Homeopathic physician at the request of Maria & others, who cured my head

entirely with two little powders, have'nt had a bit of ache since! Mrs. Hopkins live at Elyria. I presume Anne has written you from Elyria before now. Little Mr. Percie enjoys riding exceedingly - unlike his sucker cousin, he never thinks of closing his eyes, unless he rides a great distance - just as wide open as can be from here to Mr. Crosby's, four miles. His father says, tell' em he can beat the sucker cousin at anything he has a mind to undertake - he has just been asking him to make his mark! I can't tell the cause of my head pain - both physicians though it of a nervous character the same irritation which has been in my system, only in a different form & aggravated by nursing. I feared one while I should have to wean the baby. We have had some excessively hot weather lately. I think it is enough to make one's head ache pretty hard to think about training up a baby. In great haste - Samuel waiting - much love and many kisses for wife and baby.
Lucy.

Lucy. Bangor Sept. 22. 1853
                                                                                                                                          Du Quoin Oct. 6, 1853
                                                                                                                Bangor Sept. 22. 1853

Dear Brother & Sister

                             With my little springing jumper in my Cap I am sitting at the desk trying to write, because I can't wait, to ask you what you think of the news from Elyria, which you have undoubtedly received before now. For my own part, I am so astonished I don't know what to say. I jumped up and down in spite of my infirmities! Just think of it. What a queer termination of Anna's and Lizzie's arrangements about going to Chicago to teach - a couple of forlorn spinsters - both married and settled in life in the course of three weeks, both unthought of & unpremeditated, - sudden matches. I do hope they will prove happy ones. The burning of the school-house, Mrs. Hopkin's urgent invitation,  and all together, it seems to me we must look at it as all directed by the hand of Providence. For my part, I am so delighted I hardly know what to do with myself. I am so glad for Anna - and also truly glad for you that the town is to be to Illinois. Though we had a little hoped

left-hand side and top nothing more. I wish it might be all written off plainly, so as to be easily read, and carved in such sort that it can be presumed. I have done so much to it myself that I don't want to lose my labor! You and Anna must confer about it. Do write soon and often. Aff'y sister Lucy. Nettie's good letter of Sept. 3 was rec'd a few days since.

they would come to Maine, we certainly are not selfish enough to regret that you have the pleasure instead. But is'nt it "so queer" and so good. From her description of the gentleman he must be a man worth having - but you have lost your good winter's visit. I would be sorry for you if I was'nt so glad for Anna that I can't be sorry for any thing - she did'nt write his name in her first letter. Maria and I imagined it out "Peleg Perkins! "De Weir" is quite a nice name. Lizzie Doe Thaxter is boarding at Mr. Simon Pearson's, quite near Eliab's boarding place. She and her husband are both quit exquisite in their tastes. Their rooms are fitted out beautifully. A great many little ornaments, pictures etc. showing very fine taste. Baby & I spent the day with Maria day before yesterday. Samuel came to dinner. Lizzie called and staid an hour or two. I enjoyed the day much. Maria insists than they are coming here this winter whether we consent or not. It will certainly be very pleasant if Samuel & Eliab are both away some, as they probably will be. Samuel is sending supplies into the woods preparatory to another winter's operations. We have

just had quite a rain. Samuel hoped enough to bring down his logs, but he thinks not; he says there was hardly ever such a season known before - no rise of water from June till Sept. Logs are so high, that his business will not favorably prove so profitable this year as last. I have had two letters from Mother - she is deliberating about going to N.H. It seems hard to her to go alone. I know if she had somebody to go with her she would go. Did I tell you in my last letter that Father Sawyer - 98 years old - preached one evening not long since, an hour and twenty five minutes! his hearers were weary if he was not. Our little P.P. Percie prospers finely- as great a hand for a frolic as you ever saw - he begins to show considerable understanding of matters & things, especially when we play with him - he holds playthings and throws them about at a great rate - and almost sits alone. would before now if I had strength of back to work over him & teach him how. I will put in a bit of his hair - see if it is not very like in color to your baby's. By the way, we all regret that you did not decide upon Du Quoin for his name. I really

wish you would now. My health is excellent. I gain strength constantly, and can walk better than for nearly three years before. I do not walk out doors much, but think I shall soon walk out into some of the neighbors! Homeopathy entirely cured my head! I am very glad to hear that you are gaining strength, Nettie, but I am fearful you will get the ague and love it again. Do use every precaution, both of you, against it. How I wish you could some east a few weeks & enjoy our cool, bracing, delightful weather. Little Lizzie is here - a nice little girl, only she wants to read, read, read, the whole continual time. I can't think it is good for her. I hope you write often to her Mother - she is very sad and lonely. My baby grows so far, Nettie, that I have hard work to keep him in clothes! Am just making him some new shirts, and shall be obliged to put on winter dresses sooner than I care to because he is outgrowing his others. How much we want to see you. We have wanted you both to help is talk & wonder about Anna. Isaac, what shall be did with the book? It is really interesting, & ought to be finished up, for our own comfort, if nothing else. If,

Lucy. Bangor Oct. 15 1853
                                                                                                                                                              Du Quoin, Nov. 3. 1853
                                                                                                                                  Bangor Oct. 15, 1853

Dear Brother & Sister

                                          Your last good letter to Mother if at Bangor, and to sister Lucy "when or no'," was received some days since; I have intended every day to write, but "there is always something" to prevent and take up my time. I am not hurrying to make baby's flannel dresses, the autumn winds are blowing and he needs them. Mother came a fortnight ago today - went to Milo last Wednes. We tried to keep her here, but she thought she must go and help Albina get ready for winter. I think she will come back by & by. I hope so, not only on my own account, but because I think she can be more comfortable here in the cold weather. Lizzie is drawing Percie out on the sidewalk and I am improving the time.  He is very good indeed, but yet you know a babe needs something done about constantly.  He frequently plays an hour at a time without a bit of my care, lips sticking out, talking away as earnestly as you 

[left-hand side and top] do up my letter for Samuel to take. I presume Eliab keeps you advised in regard to the Temperance movement. He is very much engaged in it. Please to continue to keep on being good, and write often and much to me. Most affectionately, sister Lucy. write what is to be done with the Manuscript in your next.

can think. The noise he makes mostly about his play is a sort of gutteral grunt continued as long as he can hold his breath. He had two cunning little teeth, & others almost through. He was christened a fortnight ago tomorrow- was just as good as baby could be. At five months he weighed almost 20 pounds. Don't you call him a great nice baby. His eyes at a little distance look quite black, but nearer are a decided gray. Samuel and I went to a musical concert last evening - gone more than three hours. baby slept some & waked some - good all the time. I do so want to see your little (Du Coigne, I call him)  that I can hardly wait. You will come next summer, won't you? I do hope you will all escape the ague - it would be so hard for baby. Lizzie is a dear good little thing - but she is "so ittle" - she is not healthy. I don't think she will live many years. She is held up as a pattern of goodness in school here. Strange news from Milo. Mrs. Dr. Kimball has been accused of stealing, her house searched & various articles found belonging to other persons. A part of them she tried to account for. The Dr.

feels it very much indeed - he is so strictly sternly upright that I don't think he would spare or try to shield his own wife, if he thought her guilty - he is investigating the matter as well as he is able. I want to hear the conclusion. I do not yet believe but there will be some explanation to clear her - it is so dreadful for those children. I suppose you have had a nice good visit from Mr. and Mrs. De Witt before now. I am in great haste to hear your opinion of the man and everything about them both. Ought she not to send us his daguerreotype?  We have not yet found out his name - only the initial, E. I expect it is Ebenezer, Elnathan, Eldad, or some such name; Anna has been pretty severely disciplined in various ways, and I do hope the rest of her days may pass smoothly & happily. But I cannot cease to wonder at the turn events have taken.

              Maria and Eliab are coming here to board as soon as the river closes. She is a real good sister - we love her much. She come quite often to see me - we are anticipating nice times this winter, only, Samuel will be away a good deal, and Eliab too, some, I expect. I thought

when Samuel had a baby to crow to him, he could be kept at home! He and Mr. Bradeau will "operate" about as much as last winter. It is rather an unfavorable time, everything is so high. Samuel has bought Charles's Nelly for this winter. Maria and I are going with her to make some calls some day before long. I can get into a carriage alone now, though I don't do it very often. I have gained health & strength within a month very much, notwithstanding I have such a heavy baby to lift & take care of - he sits alone a little - would have done so nicely before now, had I strength of back to help him more, but to make it easy for myself, I keep him sitting in his carraige most of the time. We have an excellent girl now - pleasant, smart, neat and quick  - takes care of Percie beautifully. I go to church half of every sabbath. I do wish you could enjoy some of our good sermons. Mr. Shepard has preached two upon the characters of Peter & John lately - he thinks that together they made a whole team! Maria and I often wish Nettie could stop in and spend the afternoon with us. We think of you much & feel how much you miss and need brotherly and sisterly intercourse to comfort. It is dinner time. I must

Bangor Nov. 11 . 1853.

Dear Brother & Sister

                                     I cannot possibly tell whether I have written since receiving your last letter or not. If I have not, I thought a good deal about it, intended to, and finally thought I had, and so out it out of my mind, or rather let it pass out, for a few days. Not that you are out of my mind so long at a time, by any means, though.
               It is now before breakfast, though seven o'clock and later than we usually breakfast, but Samuel was out on his police duties till two o'clock last night, and he sleeps late. The little Percie is in his carraige at play. Isobel waiting for the folks to be ready for breakfast, and I am improving the few spare moments. Samuel and his brother watchmen as they came to the square at the foot of State street, heard a noise as of a man groaning, and following the sounds, found quite a clearly dreaded,

[left-hand side and top] filled my sheet with nothings, as usual. I am not guilty of sending much blank paper, though I cannot boast of covering it with much that is valuable. How much I do find to do all the time. Do you get time to read Nettie? I cannot. But keeping house brings more care than boarding. Pickles, pressures or somethings all the time spoiling if not attended to. Do write very often to your ever affectionate sister Lucy. Samuel sends love - he is full of care and business preparations for winter, lumbering etc. many kisses for little _ _ _ _

respectable looking yenkee, drunk, lying in the gutter on the hard paving stones at the corner of Broadway and State streets. They got him up, quite chilled, helped him over to the watch house, made a fire, warmed him, found out who he was, and took him to the Hatch house to lodge this was about twelve o'clock. His name was Whitney, from Troy. The clerk at the Hatch house knew him & was greatly surprised to see him in such a state. The man appeared much ashamed, said he had not been so before for ten years.

  It is almost noon. I have swept and "put in order" the sitting room, "seen to the dinner", taken care of my vegetable plants and my "olive plant". The latter has had his nap, and now sits upon the floor with his little red flannel dress, white linen apron and bright eyes, making havoc with his box of playthings, crowing, laughing, squealing & grunting by turns as the fit takes him  - he is a great hand to laugh out loud - loves to frolic dearly. To my partial eye, he is really quite a fine looking little boy! I don't feel

a bit ashamed of him - don't believe I should beside his "sucker cousin"! Should'nt we all love to see them together? You wish, Nettie, that you were nearer your Mother, that she might teach and assist you in training the little one. I truly wish you could be, more however, for the comfort of your mother and yourself than the benefit to the child, for I imagine that you and Isaac will meet with respectable success in governing him; though truly, I suspect we neither of us know much about the matter yet. Percie has shown his "Adamic nature"  little once or twice - we have begun to govern him as much as to have him lie still & go to sleep by being sung to when he wakes in the evening. He is very good about it 0 since has cried but a few moments, and then apparently "more in sorrow than in anger." I don't know who needs heavenly wisdom if a parent does not, and we have the comfort of knowing that it will be freely given if sought for in humble sincerity. I want Mother should stay with me

Lucy - Bangor Nov. 11. 1853
DuQuoin. Nov. 26, 1853
this winter, but don't know whether she will. How can I stay lone with Isabel and the baby when Samuel is away? I did expect Eliab and Maria to stay here this winter, but they are really talking seriously of emigrating to Illinois or Kentucky or somewhere else. Eliab thinks he must be in business somewhere, and Maria says he shall not go away alone. If you persuade Charles away to Ill. Mother will think she must stay at Milo with Albina, so I shall be all alone. I do not wonder that you want some own folks there with you, and I am sure I would be willing to be lonesome one winter, at least, if by that meaning you could be so comforted. I believe I have written you of the accident to our church by the storm & wind - it is nearly repaired now - I think Lizzie will not stay here another term now - she is getting tired & nervy. I have grieved a great deal for you because Anna could not go to DuQuoin. She sent her own & husband's daguerreotypes recently to us. He is a fine looking man - well I have

Bangor. Lucy. Nov 22, 1853
Du Quoin Dec 3-1853
Bangor Nov. 22 - 1853
Very dear brother & sister
Another good letter from you jointly, arrived yesterday, making the second since I have written, though I sent one but a few days since, the very day, I think before receiving your first. In that you mention not having received any letters from Bangor for six weeks, & not knowing whether Mother was in Bangor or not. I cannot understand it - some letters must have been lost - I wrote immediately after Mother arrived here from Mass. and again as soon as she left here for Milo, stating those facts. Then I have certainly written as many as two letters since. Mr. Crosby & folks have not had letters from William for five or six weeks. Oh, how much they want him with them now! They are heavily smitten - Dear Margaret, the loving and the loved, has gone. She died day before

yesterday - sabbath - in the afternoon, very peacefully and easily. She suffered very much for the last few weeks, but was so sweetly patient, and thankful for everything that was done for her - wondered why people were so kind to her, &c. &c. I hardly know how her parents will bear up under this heavy blow. Every body seemed to love Margaret. We shall go down this afternoon to the funeral. I have half a dozen letters that I ought to write this forenoon, besides ever so much else to do, so you will excuse me if I write hastily, as I am sorry to say I usually do.
I am delighted to hear such favorable accounts of the little "Sucker." I don't care if all the sucker women covet him, provided his parents are able to resist every temptation to part with him for a bigger one. In regard to the cousins looking alike, Nettie, I fancy not, if yours looks like a girl, has small features &c. Percie has not large features - about middling - but is a very boy in his looks, as ever you saw - his whole face, form of the head

and neck show him to be a baby boy. I was never asked, "Is it a boy or a girl?" He has a wide awake, earnest, inquiring expression of countenance, and yet very placid, particularly his eye, which is quite large, and, I think, growing darker. His head is very large above his eyes and ears, full & high in front & projecting behind. In short he is a most wonderful & perfect little baby boy - ask his father if he is'nt! You know it is said there are but few perfect things in the world, one of which is the first baby! As to baby's dress - First; Isaac, you need'nt trouble Nettie because she makes many & various articles - she can't help it - their name is "legion", is'nt it Nettie? Why when my baby wore white, I had to allow a clean dress every day, and sometimes more - now, two aprons in a day - he does not drool nor throw up milk so much as a while ago, so I can keep his dresses sweet, and flannel does not show dirt like white. He wore loose slips (with a little crossway yoke about an inch wide, piped at the

bottom & drawn at the top with a small string so as to look like a piping, till he was three or four months old, - has worn waists since, as he grew out of his slips. His winter dresses are made with waists) at the top, form little plaits laid over & stitched down to form the shoulder strap. The waists are full, with a belt, guaged about a quarter of an inch above & below the belt, and below the band at the neck. The sleeves and bottom of the skirt are also buttonholed in scollops with saddler's silk. They look cunningly pretty, albeit 'tis a good deal of work to make them, and I think I should eschew embroidery next time. After babies get just as big as ours are now, I think waists look prettier than slips; and I suppose Isaac as well as yourself will allow that to look pretty is of great importance! Do you make long sleeves? I did not but have almost repented since, though short ones do look prettier. How do you make sa'ques? If your baby drools as Percie has, he must wear

aprons, & do you have sacques too? I keep little bibs on under the dress to protect his flannel, and aprons outside. Does your little - (I wish you would really decide on a name & tell me what to call him) wear socks? Mallie made a beautiful little pr of shoes (salmon thibet embroidered - chain stitch - with blue saddler's silk) for Percie, but they are too small - We have some idea of sending them by mail to you. But, Nettie, why don't you regain your strength - it is time: - I suppose your climate is debilitating & enervating - particularly to one reared on the hills of N. Eng. If nursing keeps you down, ought you not to wean the babe? It would be hard, I know, but I almost had to do it for my head ache. Certainly should, had I not betaken myself to a homeopathic physician just as I did. Really I think you ought to be strengthened up in some way, and not try to keep along so. I thought it was against Isaac's principles and practice to allow any pain, sickness or weakness! I have grieved not a little over

your disappointment in not seeing Mr. and Mrs. Elijah DeWitt. However if the chief pleasure is in anticipation, you did not lose the whole. I hope you will come East next Spring without fail, stop at Elyria on your way & take them with you for company. Anna seems very happy, judging from her letters, particularly in the care of her petit daughter. In her last (to Mallie) she gave a particular description of her home. It must be a very pleasant place. The desired daguerrotypes have arrived. He is a fine looking man - rather grave - but you know daguerrotypes are usually more so than is natural. O, I do so want to see her! and brother Elijah, too! I hope you write to Almeda as often as you can - she is very sad - seems to feel Lucy's death more and more - I think we can none of us realise how great the loss is to her - she needs the loving sympathy which Lucy was ever so ready to give, & which Almeda had learned to rely upon so much. Lizzie is here yet - I don't know whether she will remain through the winter or not - She is

in better health than a while ago - It is now Thanksgiving vacation - a week and a half - in which time she will get finely recruited. Maria said it would be naughty, & Eliab should have nothing to do with persuading Charles away from his family. Mother wrote a little as if C. thought of going. I think E. and M. are rather getting off the notion of going. The journey would be exceedingly unpleasant and fatiguing for Maria at this season, and equally so returning in the spring. Baby lies on the floor, his face laid down on his two hands which are stretched out before him, quite little dog fashion. He seems to keep tipping over as if he intended to creep ere long. He learned himself to sit alone - I never took any pains with him, kept him sitting in his carriage mostly, till one morning I chanced to sit him on the floor and there he sat upright most all the forenoon. What is the reason of your neuralgia, Isaac? Why don't you cure it at once? "It is sinful, besides being foolish to bear pain! I never do." As for

the Manuscript - It is not written as you speak of - only written off once, needing various corrections, expurgings &c, divisions into chapters, suitable titles, mottoes &c provided. In its crude unfinished state, it reads pretty well, I think - perhaps I am partial - I really wish you could see, read & pass judgment upon it - I think it a pity to have so much labor lost! Anna has it - I wish she would send it to you. How much I wish, Nettie, that you & Isaac could step in occasionally and see us all. E. and M. spent Thanksgiving here - several other fraternal individuals were invited but did not make their appearance. Mallie says she hears she ought to write to you, but 'tis so hard to write to one she has never seen - It is time for me to be getting ready to go to Hampden - what a big bunch of nothing I have written & how fast I have written it - you ought to write often, I am sure, when you use such ittle  sheets of paper.
Most affectionately
Sister Lucy
[left side]
Lizzie Doe (Mrs Thaxter) has been quite sick - bleeding at the lungs again - some better, I believe.

Lucy, Bangor Dec. 16, 1853
Du Quoin, Jan, 8/53.
Bangor Dec. 18 - 1852
Very dear brother & sister
Your good eight paged letter of Nov. 19 - came to hand some days since. I thank you both very much, and reproved myself for not answering it before now, though I despair at the commencement of writing either so good or so long in one to you. Of course, I cannot have so much interesting matter to communicate as you have these constantly. We have had no snow (except a little once or twice which melted almost as fast as it came) until within a week, and warm ploughing weather almost all the time. Lumberers have had the blues considerably. Some have been obliged to drive their teams out of the woods. Samuel would have been obliged to do the same very soon if this cold weather and snow had not come. He will write to you all about his affairs as soon as he can find time. You can hardly imagine how continually busy he has been, both

both day and evening for many weeks. Last week he started for the first time to go into the woods, got as far as Mattawamkeag where he met Mr. Bradeen coming out with the bodies of two of the men who were drowned while going from one camp to another, seeking their own pleasure Sabbath night. Samuel returned with them, and has now gone up Milo way, hoping the lakes are frozen so that he can start supply teams in by "the widders", as the cattle will probably have to be put on allowance before supplies can reach them.
Eliab went to Map. a week ago last Tuesday - we have not yet heard from him - Our good Mother came down Thursday, to our great delight and comfort - It is very lonely here now Samuel & Eliab are both away. Samuel will not be gone so much as usual this winter. Charles' poor colt is dead at last - It is hard for him, is it not. Albina is nice and well - does her work with the help of Maria Ricker who goes to school. I am hoping to go to Milo and Brownville next time Samuel

goes. Almeda does not write very often They have a great deal of work to do. I am very glad you feel so much more pleasantly situated than at Jonesboro; though I am sorry for you both that Isaac must be away so much - It does not seem hardly right, does it Nettie, to have our "hubs" go off and leave us so much - certainly it is not agreeable - though we have both so many comforts and blessings that we ought not to complain of that deprivation. Mr. Crosby called a few days since. He seems much pleased about William. We have read "Wide, wide world" - It is truly a dear book. Samuel bought recently Cheevers 'Stories of Nature to her foster child the soul of man." It is so very good, I hope you will have an opportunity to read it if you have not already. It is full of sweet and great thoughts. Mother says you complain justly that I do not write enough about my own health - I tell her it is such an old story that I forget it. I have not been so well since we moved as before - though quite comfortable and able to do considerable

about house most of the time. I have been to church but once since you went from here - I went one evening with Sam'l to see the "Seven mile mirror" - truly well worth seeing - the view of the "thousand isles" alone would have well repaid me for the trouble and fatigue. Sarah Harlow is engaged to Mr. Marsh, one of the students. Prof. Shepards excellent thanksgiving sermon upon Maine is to be published - We shall send you a copy. His test was "The lives are fallen to us in pleasant places &c." I am sorry Samuel is not at home, Isaac, to write what you wish about lumber, steam power &c. He will do it soon after he returns. Lissie Doe has just popped in from Glenburn to spend the sabbath - so I will send this right along, as Jane is going down to the office tonight. It is fine cold weather tonight. Samuel is going to have a horse and a real handsome pung this winter, so I expect to take comfort riding when he is at home - 

In haste and with much love
Sister Lucy.

Bangor Dec. 19 - 1853
Dear Sister Nettie
It is Saturday evening - The dear husband is away for a week - his first trip in the woods - My little bird has hushed his song & lies quietly with closed peepers; Eliab and Mallie are in their room - Mallie keeps Saturday instead of Sabbath evening - Lissie & Isabel are in bed and I am left alone with a nice bright fire and my own thoughts for company. Ha! Mallie's little canary has waked up & is hopping now his cage making such a racket that I fear he will wake little Percie. The fire lights the room so much I guess he thinks 'tis morning.
Don't I wish I could just step in and spend an hour with you? I wonder if Isaac is away & you alone with baby! Or are you all three together having a dear good time? I hope 'tis the latter. Your good letter, written on those little sheets,
Written up the left side:
Does Anna write frequently to you? She seems very happy in her new home - Please take notice that any sheets are larger than yours. Prof. Shepard is sick with Pleurisy  fever - 
I getting better now I believe. Lissie Doe Thaxton is very much out of health Good night  - Affectionately Sister Lucy

I received two or three days since. What is the reason that you have such a "quantity of resting" to do? Why don't you get strong? It will never do - if that climate is so debilitating and enervating you must leave it. Why in the world don't Isaac preach over some of his old sermons to you? Really, though it is no laughing matter - can't you do something, or take some time? I have desired benefit (and so has Mallie) from what we call cinnamon cordial - It is very palatable & strengthening - I make it often. Dissolve a quantity of gum arabic in hot water - have it as thick as is pleasant to drink - put considerable loaf sugar to it & cinnamon enough to flavor it nicely, then add a little wine or brandy to make it keep well, & to take off the flat taste of the gum arabic. Bottle it up and take a swallow or more, whenever you feel like it. I wish you would try it. It cannot hurt you if it does no good.
I suppose Charles has arrived at DuQuoin before now - we are depending upon him

to judge impartially in regard to the good looks & good behavior of the rival babies! Percie was quite ill two or three days last week - we were up with him considerable two nights - the first time since he was a week old. He seems perfectly well now - had two teeth when five months old & no more yet, though he will soon have, I think. When six months old he weighed as much as little Mary at a year old - Samuel weighted her when at Milo a few days since. Mother has gone to Brownville this week - is coming here after making Almeda a good visit. She has been really sick lately, though she called it only a bad cold - perhaps she has written to you - she seemed rather low-spirited when she wrote last. Eliab & Malli have been here a little more than a fortnight - They seem to enjoy life finely - For your especial consolation, Isaac, I will just mention that Eliab holds Mallie in his cap & kisses her with great apparent gusto! For which misdeeds, I, of course,

Lucy. Bangor Dec 17. 1853
Du Quoin. Jan 3. 1854
feel bound to reprimand him, as I did your honor for days of yore! We have had most delightful weather for a long time - like Sept. and Oct - no snow yet, but plenty of mud. Long time ago there was a cold time, the river froze up suddenly & unexpectedly, closing in three steamboats & sixty vessels. Ship owners, merchants &c. quarrelled energetically for a day or two about getting them cut out, when the weather moderated & the ice left for "parts unknown" of its own accord. Though, I believe there was a good deal of cutting done. Mallie says she knows she ought to write, but 'tis so hard to write to those she has never seen. She has had a splendid present - a pin,(mosaic) sent from Rome. Charles will tell you about it. I never knew a person have so many presents before; rich ones, too. I have not been to Mr. Crosby's since the day Margaret was buried - have been waiting for sleighing - Tell William we deeply sympathize with him in the loss of his excellent sister. My love to him. Do please write often -
Written up the left side:
Eliab has recently bought The life of Isaac T. Hopper - We do not like it near so well as he expected-
Written on the right side:
Does Anna write frequently to you? She seems very happy in her new home -

Sister Lucy Bangor
Jan 20. 1854
Du Quoin Feb. 4 - 1854
Bangor Jan. 20 - 1854-
Dear Brothers & Sister
I am writing today partly because I feel particularly stupid and unfit to do any thing else!, and partly because I have a little unoccupied, or rather unappropriated time, as it is a very snowy afternoon and Eliab is good enough to stay in the house and help take care of Percie. The poor little fellow has been quite sick yesterday & last night with an attack of croup - He is yet very hoarse with a wheeze at every breath - The danger is over now, unless he should get more cold. Samuel is away. I would have given everything to have had him at home yesterday, but am glad now to have him spared so much anxiety as he would have felt had he been at home. We were alarmed and sent for Dr. Paine - Dr. Mc. Ruen was out of town & I doubt if we should have sent for him had he been home -

All seemed in favor of Homeopathy excepting myself, and I was quite ridiculed. The cold water on his throat & stomach, or the medicine, has certainly relieved him. We have had a short letter from you & Eliab one from Charles, since he arrived at DuQuoin. We are troubled about Nettie's health. Will she not be obliged to come east in order to recover her health? She must do something and get well. It will not do to go on so in that climate. I really wish, Nettie, that you would try the cordial I wrote about. We all derive benefit from it. Health is worth more than money or rail-roads for both of you. This way off, cold, down east country is best, after all, I think. I so much want to see your little Du Coign and as much I wish you could see our little bright eyed Percie with his good natured face - He is so patient and good when sick. Mother came with Sam'l a week ago last Saturday - What could I have done without her last night? We expect Almeda when Samuel comes next time, to stay

a few days. Prof. Shepard has been quite sick with Pleurisy fever. E. and M. attend the Mercantile Lectures - Richard M. Cana, Josiah Quincy, Dr. J.C.V. Smith, Mr. Burlingane, Dr. Anderson, Prof. Shepard &c &c We have good times here together this winter - Eliab is reading loud evenings McFarland's history of Japan, and Nelson's Cause & Cure of Infidelity - both very interesting books.  We had no snow until January, then the greatest quantity of snow fell in six days ever known to fall here in that length of time. It blew into drifts so much that there was not very good sleighing - considerable bare ground - since then, a great rain storm & thaw which carried the snow almost entirely away - now another warm snow storm. Samuel bought old Nellie of Mr. Gould, but she had the spavin, so he sold her to Mr. Buroughs for 60 dollars less than he gave, and bought Mr. Kittredges' horse for $150. It is quite a pretty creature & will be gentle with a little training. Were you not really

astonished to get so long a letter from Eliab? I presume you have received it before now. We tell him he is naughty about writing - and Mallie says she cannot write to people she has never seen - We were all delighted to receive your daguerrotype, Isaac, but wish Nettie's influence over you was sufficient to remove the slouched hat and whiskers. You must be good and submit yourself to her better judgement in regard to some matters. It is most right. I am tired, and baby will need me - good night all dear ones - Charles do write to me - a good long letter, soon. With much love to all -
Sister Lucy

Bangor FEb. 1 -1854.

Dear Sister Nettie

                          Eliab received today a letter from Charles dated Dec. 27 - saying that you and Isaac had both been most sick; that Isaac was better, but you not much. This rather alarmed us, for we thought it was still another ill turn, until we compared dates & found we had received letters with an account of the same illness, from you and Isaac, dated Jan. 3rd and 6th. Still we are far from feeling at rest about either of you.
  Mother has really been trying to persuade Eliab to write immediately to Isaac for permission to go on to Illinois for the purpose of safely escorting you and "Du Coign" home to New England. Eliab seems very anxious about you. He says you ought to come immediately home to your Mother, and I think so too. Much as we should all want to have you here with us, I do not doubt that it would be better for you to be on those New Hampshire hills where you were born and bred, for a time until you had in part recovered your health & strength.
  We are all worried about you. I want you should be packed off to New England forthwith. I am "out of conceit" that that most delightful Illinois climate, and feel very anxious to have you all

[left-hand side and top] sometimes we have to coax him a long time to get him to open his bill at all, and when he does he will laugh, smack his lips, rub his feet together & make a great ado over a bit as big as a pea. Mother says she never saw a child that cared less about food. Do please write next time that you are gaining strength fast & have concluded to come East early in the spring. This is a sad-looking letter. Maria says she is really intending to write to you soon. I have not had a letter from Anna for a long time. Mother says "tell them I think of them, love them and pray for them." Why don't Charles write to me? Love to him, as also to yourself. A kiss for baby. good night. Sister Lucy.

away from it. What is money, what are railroads, what are townships of land, compared with health? It seems to me that you are all losing your health and vigor and strength of constitution, and I wish Isaac would arrange his business so that he can leave, and come away. I think he had better send his wife and boy by express, and follow on himself as soon as he settle up matters so as to leave. I am quite uneasy to have Charles out there, and want he should without fail start for home before the hot, debilitating summer weather approaches. I do sympathize with you in your sorrow and disappointment at being obliged to wean the baby. I know it was hard for your feelings, though perhaps easier for the little one, than it would be after getting older and more attached to his dinners! I am intending to wean Percie in April. I dread it, both on his account and my own. 'Tis a comfort to nurse him, and he takes so much comfort in it, it seems hard to deprive him of it. He is quite well now. It took him several days to get over his croup. I was so frightened and Samuel was away too. He is so fat & healthy that I fear he will be subject to such attack. He has never been out doors enough. It has been unfortunate for him that I have not been able to take him and run out when I pleased. However

we will try to make up all deficiencies in that respect when another summer comes if we live. Won't we have good times with the little darlings when you come? Do please to make haste and get here. Mallie is a famous hand to frolic with babies and take care of them and love them. I am anxious to know that you are trying my cordial, it is so good, not only as a general tonic, but particularly beneficial in diarrhea as Maria can abundantly testify from her last summer's experience. Why a chronic diarrhea is a bad thing, and must be stopped! You will run down and wear all out if it is not. How gladly I would help you to some good water if I could. If Isaac will bring or send you right here, you shall have all you want.

    Eliab seems to be rather unfortunate about property lately. He feels blue, though he does not worry not say much about it. The "Susan Duncan" has been an unfortunate vessel from the first; is three years old & has never made one good trip yet: he has never received a dollar from her, but had paid out a good deal. he has recently had letters from the captain at Savannah with an account of loss and damage to the amount of a thousand dollars. Several little annoying losses & crosses in his business besides. He feels poor, and I suppose

Lucy. Bangor Feb. 1. 1854                     Feb. 18
Du Quoin Feb. 18, 1854. 
is really so. Samuel went away yesterday again, He came home a week ago bringing Almeda with him. She and Lizzie went home with him. Our winter thus far has been quite mild with the exception of a few cold days last week, where it was from 20 to 35 degrees below zero. Samuel is, as usual, full of business. His teams are doing very well in the woods, but everything is so high that I fear he will not make a great deal. He had some corn, flour etc. to buy when he came out last; it was so high, he thought he would wait a few days for it to fall, but it only grew higher, so that he paid upwards of fifty dollars more for what he purchased this time than he would had he bought when he first came home. $1.25 for corn, 12.50 for flour- that is extra flour, such as he gets for the house - his woods flour only $11.00

       We imagine that Charles is disappointed in your country, because he is so mum! he does not tell us a word of what he is doing or how he likes. According to Isaac's account, your baby eats astonishingly. There is a great difference in the appetites of the respective babies. Mine has never fed but little - don't want to. I fix from one to three spoonfuls o milk once or twice a day with a crumb of bread as large as a thimble; he very daintily opens his little mouth & sips down a part of it - he drinks very well, but only a little at a time.

Bangor July 24, 1854.

Dear Sister Nettie

                     Some good sisterly letter was received and read with joy saturday eve at about ten o'clock. We had worried some about you; it was so very foggy here, that we feared the boat might be detained on account of it and not get into Boston at the usual time, and so occasion trouble about meeting the cars; bit it seems you got home sooner even that you expected. Baby good too, sea not rough, Sabra not sick, and all things better than we feared. I am so glad, but sorry am I that you should find your parents in poor health. I hope that the coming home of the daughter and grandson will cheer and revive them greatly. It is a hot day, 1/2 past twelve o'clock. They have all been hot days since you went away, and very dry - not even

[left-hand side and top] and I must stop. Do dear Nettie let us try to write often to each other. I wrote to Isaac a day or two after you went away. The ship has gone to sea. Samuel was on board when she started & without intending it went off down to Castine & home in the tow-boat. Is'nt it queer that you did not after all read the Martyr. I think you will have to come again and winter with Isaac & try to make out your visit & have a good time. It troubles me every time I think of it. I were so full of care it seems as if I did not do anything to make your visit pleasant. Love to Sabra. much love to your Father.

Lucy & Mallie Bangor July 24./54
Du Quoin July 27 - 1854-
a shower to moisten the parched and dusty earth, and to replenish the almost dry cistern. Percie sit in the big rocking chair near me, playing with a pencil & card - nothing on but shirt and dress. I even let him go without shoes and stockings - his head is wet almost all the time. He took two or three steps alone several times the day you went away & has since been nearly across the room, but tis so warm he does not feel strong & he has some diarrhea all the time. Just as soon as "Dr. Will " has gone, I think I shall send for some Homeopathic powders!  Do remember and not show this to Anna if she should go to Dunbarton because of this last paragraph. I should not be surprised however, if they gave up going after all. The Dr. seems disinclined because of the delay etc. says they had better go some time when they have not just parted from you. They went to Milo Thursday intending to return to Bangor Wednes - day after tomorrow & leave here finally a week
[left-hand side] & Mother. and many kisses and hugs for the littleCprry Mayo. How I shall want to see you all & cannot. If Samuel can only go with

from today. It seems as if I had hardly seen them at all. They were down street almost all the time after you went away till they went to Milo, about their daguerreotypes - will have some handsome ones in frames $10. apeice, but they had to sit a great many times before they were both suited. I want and got Percie's, but it is do dark it is not pretty & I shall try again when there comes a cool day. He was still as need be. I am so sorry that we could not have got the children together. I hope your will try and get Corry's soon. Percie misses him - he looks all round the house after him. I am anxious to know if Mayo is vaccinated. Last Saturday, just a week from the time the matter was put in, Percie's arm in one spot looked a little inflamed. There is now a small fester & inflamed as large in surface as a small pear. I don't think it will do any good. I shall feel more troubled for you than for myself if Corry's did not take, because it will trouble you to get a doctor & there you will have
[left-hand side] me. I mean to go to Dunbarton this fall, but of course I don't a bit expect to. With much love, Sister Lucy

another bill to pay. Dr. McRuen came up to do it the day after you left - did not come sooner because he had no fresh matter. I don't believe Dr. Laughton's was fresh. Ellen does nicely. If I can only keep her, I shall be thankful if she stays. I hope to have time to enjoy reading some of the books you left. I fear you did not intend to leave your Fowler & Combe books. If Anna goes to Dunbarton, I will send them. If not, I will endeavor to acquire wisdom there, or - I will send them by mail if you wish any time. And the white quilt you did not take after all. If Anna goes I will send it - if not please write whether & how I shall send it? Shall I ever get mine made? Mallie has really got about her dress (french calico) in good earnest - it is almost done. I made the buttonholes & sewed on the skirt. Our Church has almost decided to settle Mr. Smyth as pastor - to preach three months this year, and six next. I have read the "Golden Legend. The poetry is beautiful, is'nt it? I should love to read it right over again. It is dinner time, 
[left-hand side] You cannot think how very lonely it seems here - the house is so still, especially when Percie is asleep.

Bangor- 
Mond. morn - 
Dear Nettie, Lucy is writing, and I must add just a line to tell you how delighted we were to hear so soon from you - I kept thinking of you all day Tuesday, supposing you would not reach home until night. I felt so troubled about your going alone. What a nice good boy little Corry was to cry none - I imagine you are now enjoying yourself extremely, with Father, Mother, Brother, & Sister, and no sewing to

do - I wrote a few lines to Isaac last week, and among other things mentioned that you had finished your sewing. I knew it would relieve him, and I could not think of anything more you had to do. Eliab also wrote him, though I fear it was but a few lines. I cannot tell you how lonely it seems here since you left. Did I not know how much you are enjoying the quiet of home I should heartily wish you back. We are expecting Anna back in a day or two. I am afraid the very warm weather prevents

any of them taking much comfort. I spent one night with a fan in my hand, and could then scarcely breathe. We had no such weather while you were here. Samuel and Eliab take turns now about going down town after tea, so that every other evening I have a nice walk up in the grove. We spent more than an hour there one night. I sleep so sweetly after such a walk. I wish you could go with us. Anna called over to see Mrs. Harlow one evening, and could not account for her being so

very formal and distant. I could very easily guess the reason, cannot you? I have just been out to gather some string beans for dinner. I wonder if you love them as well as I do. Do tell us if Sabra is to remain with you long. Has Corry any more teeth yet. Does he not need another blue pill? If we send this by the next mail, I must stop, though I have said nothing - Do write us very often, for we so love to hear from you - Good bye - Your loving Mallie -

Lucy Bangor July 20 1854 
DuQuoin Aug. 1 ---

                                                                                                                                                                                                           Bangor July 20 - 1854 

My own dear Brother Isaac 

                          How naughty I have been in not writing to you all this long time! I would "fess" a letter full if it would do any good; but perhaps Nettie has written you some of the reasons why I have had so little time to write or do any thing else. Now I have a good capable Irish girl, whom I hope to keep some time. Nettie, Sabra and little Corry started for Dunbarton last Monday morning. After waiting so long for Anna the concluded at last to go without her; and now the Dr. and Anna have about decided that they had better not go to Dunbarton. They say they have been gone a good while & spent a good deal of money, and if they go there it will add to the expense and hinder them still more time - they say they have just parted from her & had better

go some other time when they have not just seen her. I am afraid Nettie will feel disappointed, if not hurt, about it, after waiting so long for her. I have rather urged her to go, but they will decide to themselves, of course. They went to Milo today, expect to come back next Wednesday and leave here finally the monday after. I have worried myself a good deal because it seemed to me that Nettie could not enjoy her visit here in the midst of so much confusion; Changing help, having no help etc. etc. I never had such a time of weariness and discouragement before - one day Samuel went after eleven different girls without being able to get one. If Ellen (who is here now) will only stay till E. and Mr. go to housekeeping, I shall feel thankful. Samuel got so desperate he said he would give a girl eight dollars a week if they asked it. I am afraid Nettie got most worn out before she got home. I imagine Sabra

would not do to lean upon much in such a case, and Corry was not at all well -cutting teeth or something made him nervous and irritable. The babies were both vaccinated Sat. before she went - Percie's did not take - I want very much to know if Corry's did; it will be so much trouble for her to get it done again. The Dr. and Anna have been having their daguerrotype, full length in large open frames, gilt, ten dollars apiece. Anna had Joseph's too, copied in a large frame. We went down with them & got Percie's - 'tis not very good & we are going to try again. He was still as a mouse and the position is very good, and expression good, but the light was not strong enough & the whole picture is very dark. There is great disappointment at Milo because Charles does not come - I do feel afraid to have him stay through all the hot weather, I am afraid his health will suffer

for it. Tell him a am very sorry not to write him more letters, but time is a scarce commodity now-a-days, I presume Nettie has written you all the items of interest. If she had not been here writing so often, I dare say I should have stolen time to write now and then. Mrs. Kimball has been prosecuted - the trial comes off next Saturday. We are having very hot weather now - dry and dusty too. We are apprehensive that it will be sickly. Do you & Charles both, be very careful of your health now in this sickly summer season. We see by the papers that the cholera is about you - Percie walked three or four steps alone the day Nettie went away, for the first time - today he has walked almost across the room - Corry seems stronger - is more forward about walking than he. Well he is crying and teasing me to take him - good bye - with much love to both of you - Sister Lucy

Lucy. Bangor Apr 12, 1854
Du Quoir Apr 24, 1854
Bangor Apr. 12-1854
Dear Sister Nettie
Your last good letter of Mar. 18, written "all, all alone," while Isaac was gone to St. Louis, was received some days since, as also one from Charles, which I answered immediately. We were very sorry to learn, by Charles' letter, that you had not been so well again - I think I know how to sympathize with you in two particulars - viz. frequent absences of the dear husband, and backsliding in the matter of health; both which trials are great ones to me. It seems so hard when one, with great carefulness and patience, has just got nicely up, beginning to feel strength and vigor, and so hopeful of better days to come; to do a little too much, or take a little cold, and fall back to the old place again; yet, I know these are among the lesser trials, and should be considered so. O, how small compared with the lot of friends! There it is so
[left side and on top]
you to speak of it. Mallie had sent to her, (received yesterday) two beautifully worked ottoman covers and a very handsome tidy. Did you ever know anybody have so many handsome presents? Her relatives are all wealthy and thus the southern girls where she taught a good while, are famous for their generosity - you know. Well, I must put by my writing. A kiss for the little one and for Isaac. good bye - your loving sister Lucy

and He cannot do wrong.
"To lack the loving discipline of pain
Were endless loss."
I had almost forgotten the old back aches and lounge lying through the winter, I was so well and smart, but while Isabel was gone home, I did a little too much, and lifting the baby so much learning to stand & has been rather too hard, so that I have had to betake myself to the lounge and be careful. My old ailments and weaknesses have troubled me, and I have been trying to get a woman to come and relieve me of the care of Percie, and stay till after I wean him, which I intend to do this month. I suppose it is a great undertaking to wean a baby, but don't know much about it. Percie is very tenacious of titty, and I imagine he will not be denied very easily. I wrote so much to Charles about Percie that I will not fill this letter about him. Of course to us, he

is the dearest, cunningest baby to be formed! I think your little Du Coign must be quite a musical genius. I should love to see him play on the melodion! I feel in a hurry to have you leave Illinois, both on account of your health, and because I want to see you. But what will poor Isaac do all summer without his wife and baby boy? I rejoice at the arrangement because I think such attractions at the East will draw him this way sooner than he would otherwise come, and we want to see him. How hard it does seem that it is ever necessary for family to separate so far from each other! I imagine there are joyful anticipations now-a-days in one Dunbarton house, at least. Don't you? I can hardly make up my mind whether, under the circumstances, you are gladder to come to your old home, or sadder to leave Isaac. I hope he will be able to follow you soon.
This is a bright, warm, April day, so pleasant, with such a sweet, bracing air; but the snow drifts are deep and near to

gether in many places - bare ground and mud, and deep snow drifts alternate. This past winter is said to have been the most severe ever known, but for cold and snow - When Samuel came from the woods last week there was six feet of snow on an average in the woods. He thinks notwithstanding the unusual expense, he has done well lumbering - the prospect for driving the logs is good. Don't you think I am glad of the change in his business? Now he will not go away in the winter. Am I not glad also that Eliab concluded to go in with him, instead of taking himself and Mallie away off to N. York or somewhere else? How I wish Isaac & his, and Anna and her's, could move up a little nearer, so that we could be within speaking distance.
How much comfort we are anticipating when you and Anna get here! I know I must not be selfish, but please don't stop too long in N.H. before you come here. The price on Railroads which I put in Charles' letter was intended more particularly for Isaac's benefit; I for

Lucy - Bangor March 14 1854
DuQuoin Apr 6, 1854

                                                                                                                                                                                Bangor March 14 - 1854.

Dear Brother & Sister
It is evening - half past eight o'clock; so even if Percie does not wake and call for me, I cannot write a long time. Eliab and Mallie are seated on either side the "Bagatelle" before the fire, tho one reading the last Independent, the other finishing off some Circle embroidered shoes for the "Corban." They are to have a great sale soon. Gen. Veazie tells the ladies that if they will go on & do what they can, he will help them about building a chapel for the Seminary! I have just had a letter from Samuel - he went away a week ago today & does not expect to return until Saturday - almost another week - we have had constant warm weather since March came in, - hardly cold enough to freeze at night, - which has made the "toting", particularly on the lakes, so hard that Samuel is obliged to remain with

the teams. Messrs Pendleton & Ross have made a proposition, which he considers very good, for Samuel and their present bookkeeper to buy them out - they are ship chandlers, you know - taking their customers &c. I don't know what he will do if the confinement within doors will not be injurious to his health I should like it much, as he would then be at home winters. Perhaps eventually Eliab & he might be associated together. Perhaps I had better not have written anything about it, as there are no plans formed. I have teased Eliab about writing to your Isaac, but you know he had rather do anything else then write a letter.
Lucy Stone is creating quite an excitement here just now - has delivered three lectures, tonight the last; on "The appropriate sphere of woman," "The legal rights of woman," and "Slavery" - people liked her first lecture very generally - they say her manner is quiet & graceful; her voice clear, full & sweet, and her dress simple and

appropriate - partly bloomer. We intended to hear her one evening, but did not. I feel rather disappointed. Julia Parker made me a nice little visit recently, - Isaac - She is a fine looking girl, having as I judge her mother's loquacity and her father's good sense along with it. Father Furber is married - quite recently - to a widow lady of St. Paul, 45 years of age. Bill is to be married in the Spring, and John is "wooing." 
Isabel went home to stay a few days when Samuel went last to Milo, so Mallie and I are getting along alone - I did too much the first day or two & have, per consequence, been partially overset, so Mallie has taken the reins of government. Percie is good as can be, but is learning to stand by things & requires a good deal of care - his sixth tooth is just coming through. He acts so rogueish when I tell him not to do anything he wants to. He is a happy little fellow. I expect he will be like Henry Browns little boy,

forever five years old, who said the other day, "Mother, I am so glad at noffin all the time, I don't know what to do with myself." A very happy state of things for a child, isn't it? You two good people seem to send rather contradictory statements respecting the amount for eatables consumed by Du Quoin. Percie begins to realize that he is to be weaned next month & is trying to learn to eat - we have a cow now, so he has good sweet milk, in abundance. I send another pair of shoes Nettie - you can arrange the size by the baby's foot. I did not dare to make them up to put in a letter. They will not soil so soon as the others would. I sent your last letter to Mother. I do not recollect if there was anything special in it to be answered. Please do write often & entreat Charles to do the same. It is ten minutes past nine. I have left off once to take baby up & nurse him to sleep, In excessive haste. Mallie & Eliab are

Lucy Bangor Feb 21 /54
DuQuoin March 16. /54
{Detained by the great rains}

                                                                                                                                                           Bangor Feb. 21 - 1854.

Dear Brother & Sister
It is half past eight in the evening, and my letter must necessarily be short, but I will write what I can - I have written a long letter to Anna tonight, rocking Percie with one hand meantime. Eliab and Mallie have been employed in various ways - sitting in laps? in the rocking chair, eating nuts, reading, lounging, and talking about taking a walk, but on the whole concluded to defer it till morning. Mother has gone home, Lizzie has gone home, Samuel went away again yesterday, and it seems still & lonely. Baby & I have to cuddle up alone at night as best we can - I am beginning to rejoice that the winter is most gone. He will only go twice more I expect. Percie is rather restless tonight - he has not been quite well since his last attack of croup -

The Dr. was in this morning, - he says it is teething now - his gums are swollen a good deal. He is more troublesome than ever before - just beginning to stand, and creeps very fast all over the house - when a door is open scrabbles with all his might to get out, before I catch him, laughing so hard that he can hardly go. I had to whip his hand this morning to keep him away from the tongs. He had been eating fig & was covered with it; then the black from the tongs superadded,  made me think with "Mr. Dick" of Copperfield memory, "I should wash him." He makes a cake very prettily; picks it, shutting all but the forefinger tight. I have had a nice good letter from Charles lately, which I answered immediately, also one from you conjointly, which I am now answering! I am so glad to know that your health is improving, Nettie, and if possible, gladder still to know that you are coming east in the early summer. Won't it be so nice to

come with Elijah and Anna? Poor Isaac, I shall be sorry for you as well as for the rest of us, if you are not able to come too, but you will learn a little how good it is for wife to be left alone! I imagine Albina has as hard a time of it as anybody this winter, though I think they are prospering finely now - We have not heard from Milo for some days - I presume you hear as often as we do. Did'nt  I feel dreffully when Mother went away? We have a good cow - what nice sweet milk we have! I intend now to wean Percie in Apr. We sell four or five qts of milk per day for five cts, which helps pay for keeping the cow. Walter Brown's folks had a large party last week (five hundred invitations given) - E. and M. invited, but did not go. We have had Edgar Poe's works from the Library - A sketch of him in the Eclectic reminded us to get the book - What a strange, miserable man he was! Does Anna write you often? I had a letter

very hastily written yesterday. Samuel says if there is a good freshet in the spring, so that the lumber comes down well, he shall probably do well, notwithstanding the high price of anything - don't you like the Independent better since the form is changed - It seems to me it is more interesting than before, though harder to get at. Mr. Robert Hoskins died a week or two since - I suppose he has been in Consumption for 20 or 25 years. He bequeathed to Eliab his "public documents," being several Volumes of census reports, surveys of territories &c! He has settled with Mr. Romulus Hoskins - The business was left in his hands - E. will write you about it I guess - I have hopes of him since he has written once! It is 9 o'clock - I am fidgety - have taken Percie up once since I began - & he begins to nestle again - good night all - love to all - In love Lucy.

Bangor Lucy Aug 9, 1854
Dunbarton Aug 15, 1854

                                                                                                                                                                                                              Bangor Aug. 9 - 1854

Dear Nettie
We are filled with wonderment that we do not receive letters from you - we are fearing that you or Corry or some you are sick. Mallie and I do not know whether you ever rec'd our letter written immediately after your first came from Dunbarton. Mother and Eliab and myself had good letters from dear Isaac today - How much he misses his wife and boy; and how laughably he makes complaint about it. I have been naughty - I know, in not writing to him more, but, dear me, how could I? I have written once! and mean to again soon. We want much to know whether Anna went to Dunbarton - They intended to do so when they left Bangor if the Rail roads &c. were as they expected, but the Dr. said it was uncertain & we had better not send anything

by them - he seemed to fear the Cholera & felt inclined to take the shortest route home. I do not much wonder - it really seems hardly safe journeying by railroad and steamboat now. It seems to remain healthy where Charles & Isaac are yet. I do hope it will continue so. Our dear little Percie has been very sick with teething dysentery, the Dr. called it - he was taken the day after Anna went away - he had two double teeth come through within a few days and two more badly swollen, besides his eye teeth. Sabbath day I feared we should have to part with the dear little fellow, but God has spared him to us - we know not for how long. You would hardly know him he has grown so poor and pale. His bowels particularly - there seemed to be hardly anything left but a little wrinkled skin. His appetite has returned considerably, and his bowels seem to be getting regular again. I do like homeopathy for babies at any rate. Poor Isaac is sadly afraid little Mayo

will get sick, and he says he has no confidence in the doctors there. Percie was such a dear patient little fellow - how more than ever, if possible, we loved him when he was so sick. Maria is very well and smart - Mother has had a letter from you since she came here, which she wishes me to acknowledge. I want one extremely - please favor me. We had two likenesses of Percie before Anna went away, the best of which she took & which you saw if she went to D.as I hope and suppose she did - the other we intended to change and shall, perhaps, when he gets to look like himself again. I went to see Corry's dreadfully, but I want to see Corry's self more. How does the little fellow & how many teeth has he? Percie was most faithfully vaccinated after all, though it was so long showing it? Did Corry's take at last. I am glad you got so good a carriage - I shall try to have ours fixed with the back wheels alone. You did not say whether Sabra was with you or not - Ellen stays yet, and is an excellent

girl - very pleasant - a real Irtish heart. Poor Albina's patience is almost exhausted waiting for Charles. I have just been writing to her, trying to comfort her, but it is hard work - We are most extremely obliged for the Biographical Dictionary. We had no such work in the house, and it is peculiarly acceptable. Eliab has not been very well for a few days - for myself I am slightly wearied with wakefulness & care of baby, but shall soon get recruited if he gets well - This will put him back again about walking, won't it? I suppose Mayo romps just where he pleases. Give very much love to your Father & Mother, brother & sister. I should love to go and see them all - wish Samuel could spend time & we would go by & by to help Percie grow strong & well. He is worrying for me & I must stop writing - The Cypress vine is in bloom. It is pretty. The other Illinois flower is also in blossom - Well good night. 
With much love - your sister Lucy.
Do write soon -

To the Du Quoin people.
I guess, Icus. if you come East as far as N. Hampshire and dont come to Bangor, what shall be done to you?
It is morning, six o'clock, Apr. 26 - Percie sleeps his morning nap in bed, Sam'l has just started for Oldtown in the cars. Breakfast is ready, Eliab & Mallie will be down soon, but I will improve the few moments in saying a few words, which I intended to do some days

since when I first rec'd your letter telling of Nettie's sickness. We are so glad that you are going to bring her away from Ill. immediately. I want she should be with her Mother for a time - It is the only right place for her, till she gets nicely recruited. If I could, how I would love to go on to Dunbarton by & by and see her there, but that I do not expect to do. We shall feel that it is best, and wait patiently for her to

get rested & well enough to enjoy the journey & visit, before coming to Maine, though I hope we shall not have a long time to wait. We do not begin to believe that you will come as far as Dunbarton without coming here, so you need'nt think of it. We shall follow you with - nobody knows what, if you do. I have been rather poorly myself lately, spring weather, nursing such a big baby & all together- Sent for the Dr. who said "wean baby", which I previously

intended to do this month - He is about weaned now, and I begin to feel better - have kept on the lounge a good deal lately - I do hope to be well, so as to enjoy Anna's visit when she comes - am so sorry that you & Nettie and Charles cannot be here when she is. Eliab said he wrote you yesterday - I will direct this to Elyria, as you may have left Du Quoin before is ready there - I should have written before except feeling badly & weaning Percie - Much love, 

Lucy -

Lucy
Aug. 7. 1854

                                                                                                                                                                                       Bangor Aug 7 - 1854

My own dear brother Charles
How long it has been since I have written to you or had a letter from you. If you knew all the circumstances, I am sure you would consider me excusable; and I suppose I shall think rightly if I conclude that you have been very busy and most of the time, and when you had leisure, needed it to rest and refresh yourself. You know how the brothers and sisters have been here - I have written to Isaac some of my vexations in regard to help - then Percie has been ailing a good deal by spells. He is now sicker than he has been at all before, with bowel complaint. We are feeling very anxious indeed. He has no appetite scarcely, discharges are very frequent, and seems so weak - He has been sick only four or five days, but he has lost flesh very much. You could hardly believe

him to be the same fat, hard little fellow you saw here last fall. I hardly dare to think that he may be taken from us.
