I know that he has become too precious to us, - but what a house ours would be without him - He is just as patient and quiet all the time as can be. He began to go alone considerable before he was sick, but he has not seemed very strong all summer. He has had two double teeth come through within a few days, and more are much swollen. The doctor calls it teething dysentery. We have had an unusual amount of dry hot weather. It seems to have been so everywhere. Anna left here last Monday, a week today - we feel anxious to hear from them, it has been so warm & they had some sickly places to pass through. The Dr. seemed to feel a little anxious. He is a dear good member all like him much - I rejoice that our Anna is so highly favored. I hardly know what to say about your decision to remain in Illinois so much longer.

but I fear it is not wise. I am afraid your health will suffer afterwards for remaining through the hot weather, and I always thought - Isaac himself said - that one must come from there east, in order to avoid the ague. Albina is almost in a despairing state, and it is hard. I don't think she feels any worse than I should - I dare not really express an opinion because men know so much better than we women about such things, but I fear Cholera and ague for you both. I don't love to have you come away and leave Isaac alone and I don't love to have you stay! I fear it will be a much longer time then Isaac expected before he is fairly through. Albina teases Mother and I to write & urge you to come right home, but I don't know whether I ought to or not. Dr. E. Will was dreadfully incensed against the flies and "skeeters" up country - he is nervous and they made him fidgety. I would write you about

the famous trial of Mrs. Kimball for petty larceny, but I suppose Albina will give you all the particulars. How hard it is to see a little sick, suffering baby, and not know anything what to do for it, feeling almost as if what the doctor does is stepping in the dark. The only comfort is in thinking that the Great Being who orders all events cannot do wrong. All will be just as He sees best, and then it must be right. Mother is going to write to send with this - tell Isaac not to forget to write to me if he don't have any letters for me - I have not heard from Nettie for some days - the last was a Biographical Dictionary for Sam'l "from Isaac & Nettie" - no letter with it though we have had a pretty good likeness of Percie - Anna carries one away with her. Well I must not write more now - With much love
Sister Lucy
If it will be any comfort or benefit to you or him I shall be glad to have Charlie come here after Mallie goes to housekeeping.

Lucy Aug. 24 '54
Dear Brothers

              Mother has left part of the sheet for me, so while Percie sleeps I will write. Mother has told you how poor and sick he is. We have many fears that he will not get over it, or if he does that he will be a poor, pindling little fellow a good while. It seems so sad to see him, he has always been before, such a great, fat, hearty, frolicsome fellow. Once in a while, when anything very funny happens, he make out to smile, a little sad smile, almost enough to bring tears from ones eyes. However, the bad weather is nearly over, and his big teeth, three or four at once, are getting through, so we hope he will soon be better. Mother and I have talked a little bit about taking him to Dunbarton if he gets well enough before the weather is too cold. My own health is not very good - am sort of run down and poor, and we think the journey, and comfort of seeing the good people there might be beneficial to all of us. I have been expecting a letter from Nettie for some time.
         In regard to Charles' coming home, particularly Albina's feelings about it, it is no laughing matter. She cannot bear trouble and care so well as some people, - she says her heart will break if Charles does not come - and seriously, if he stays away another winter I should have fears for her heart or her head. I do think it is

more than she can bear safely or consistently. It seems as if she might reconcile herself to it, but she can't. It only grows worse and worse. I fear Charles health would suffer if he should come this fall. You see we are all of one mind in regard to it. Samuel thinks it would have been better, decidedly, if he had come home last spring. If, on account of health, you think best not to come till spring, it seems to me that Albina had better take Josie & Mary to her Father's and stay there, let Charlie come here, and let Walter and Sally, on some terms have the house, and take care of the things. After all, I don't pretend to have judgment to advise much about it. So I won't say any more; but Albina does lay it to heart greatly.

         We are having a fine rain, though cold and raw, today; after many weeks of exceedingly dry weather. Such a month has hardly ever been known. Elia wrote you that we have had a few cases of cholera, but there is a difference of opinion about it. The papers contradict all such statements. It will be almost strange if we do not have something of it here, though now it is not sickly, except among children. I hope Corry will not have so bad a time with his teeth as Percie has, & yet I fear he will worse, because he did not begin so young, perhaps it is well that he waits till the hot weather is over. I want to see him. I do. I am very sorry for the tension of your heart strings, but what do you think of Albine with her womanly weakness? Good bye, aff. Lucy

Bangor Aug. 26 - 1854.
                 Whisk whisk away, my letter, quick, fast, to tell dear Nettie that "Energine" has come! We waited a good while for her, but this morning at 1/2 past seven, she made her appearance; a nice plump damsel is she, weighing seven pounds, and evidently inclined to make her way in the world - she nursed two time before she was an hour old! Mallie began to be sick at one o'clock - had a very comfortable time , and is very comfortable now, though, of course, she suffered a good deal, as you must know by experience. How glad and thankful we all are, and almost surprised too, that all is so well over, and that she had so quick and good a time. She had Dr. McRuen. It is now about ten o'clock - did'nt I write "quick

[left-hand side and top] your affectionate sister Lucy - do please write soon. The little Cypress vine does charmingly, and also the other little flowers. If Jenny has plenty to spare, I wish she would be so kind as to save me a few seeds of Mourning bride. Mother sends a good amount of love & will write soon.

I could- my hand trembles so I can hardly make letters. Poor little Percie is sleeping now - he has been miserable ever since Anna went away. We think he is really better though, yesterday & today, He only weighs 18 1/2 pounds  - and so poor and pale. But 'tis cooler weather and we hope he will grown strong and well now fast. I rec'd your darling good letter of the 21st yesterday - had been looking for it many days. We have all been negligent and thoughtless about making acknowledgements. Love letter to Eliab was rec'd. I don't know why he did not do anything about it, but suppose it was because of the uncertainty of Dr. De Witt's going to Dunbarton and from what you wrote. I guess he thought you did not need the money at present and he would not send it by mail. The Magazine has also been received - so all is right. Mallie also has rec'd the long letter. I rejoice that

you are all having so good times, and particularly that little Mayo is so well and smart. How I wish dear little Percie was so too, but then I hope he will be soon. I do so want to see that rogue Corry. I would send Percie's daguerreotype, but the one we have is, in a little oval frame, which cannot well go by mail. Am sorry you could not see the one Anna had that was the best. I have just scrawled a few words to Anna to tell the news. I am glad you talked with Sabra - it may do her good all her life. give my love to her - tell her if Percie knew enough he would acknowledge & return the love she sent, and also I dare say thank her for the many rides she helped him to when she was here - he is not well enough to go out in his carriage now. I am sorry about Mayo's vaccination - I don't believe Dr. Laughton's matter was good. How I would love to see the little fellow chase butterflies - kiss him and squeeze

Lucy Aug. 26 Bangor 1854
Dunbarton Aug. 29- 1854
About Energine
him hard for me. I feel as if I did not get acquainted with him, and leam him to love me as I would have been glad to when he was here; what with the care of Percie and my other cares and labors, I found little time for fondling him. Percie walked across the room - several times four or five weeks ago, but has not thought of such a thing lately, We are all reading "Homes in the new World" - like reading it very much, but in some places there is a lowering, so to speak, of the Divine character, as in Longfellow's Golden Legend, which is almost shocking to the feelings. I have not said a word to Isaac about your labors. It must have been Mallie's doings. I guess she did'nt do anything very naughty, The pricker leaves were beautiful - much obliged. I shall try and enough more to make a card basket sometime. The carpenters are finishing the stable. Mother and I have a leetle idea, if Percie gets well enough before the weather is too cold, of going to Dunbarton with him, to atone in part for Anna's not going; but don't expect us - 'tis very doubtful. Much love to all from

Bangor Sept. 3 - 1854.

Very dear Brother

             Letters from you both might before last - dear good ones too, to several of us at once - a wee bit from Isaac to me, and a nice good loving one from Charles, which deserves a special one to himself in return, and for which, - for all, - many, many thanks.
               It is Sabbath, and I feel as if I hardly ought to be writing, but Percie sleeps quietly, and whole Mother keeps the flies off, I will take time to talk a little with you. We had letters from Albina and Nettie last night, in answer to those which carried tidings of the new baby. Nettie's account of little Mayo's pranks is quite amusing. It makes my heart ache and be glad too; glad that he is so well and playful,- and sad for our poor dear little Percie. He does not seem to get any better, though his teeth (all that are swollen) are through - has had four double teeth within four or five weeks. Yesterday we called in Dr. McRuen. He told Mallie, in a funny way, that if Percie had been under a course of treatment, for the last two months, he should think his case quite discouraging, but as he had taken no medicine, he hope he could help him. He considers

[left-hand side and top] and I wrote too much about your coming home, Charles, it was all for Albina- she teased us to urge you to come. I think perhaps she is feeling a little better about it now - her letters will tell you of course - but undoubtedly you know better than any of us, and are being foolish to advise at all in the matter. Always lovingly, your sister Lucy.
[top right, upside down] a heart running over full of love and kindness to you both - in the heart of your Mother. A.M.M.

Homeopathy a "mistreatment" system in general, though he says those physicians do sometimes give medicine like others - he has detected them in it, etc. He says in many cases it is just as well, for medicine had done as much harm as good in the world. He says the danger now with Percie, is, Marasmus; a wasting away of the flesh & blood without much pain - has been so long in this state - so much action in the bowels that the food does not nourish him; is digested in the stomach, but passes off through the bowels without making flesh and blood. He seems bright and playful a good deal of the time, has a pretty good appetite, but is poor, pale and weak ; don't want to get down at all; calm, patient, pleasant - too much so, as the Dr. says; takes & does anything we want him to but has these constant and unnatural discharges - yesterday a little bloody and we though the dysentery was coming on, which was the reason of our sending to Dr. McRuen; but he had had not more bloody discharges. Well, I am filling up my letter with Percie: but I could not help it, for my mind and heart are full of him. I don't know as he is any more loveable than Mayo, as you say, Isaac, only of course to his father and mother, none other can be so precious. He is, and has always been, a dear good little boy. I suppose, of course,
[left-hand side]Percie's head & neck are perfectly wet with perspiration when he sleeps or when he is tired a little, his hands & feet hot and dry, arms and legs almost always cold.

you have got my letter telling of Energine's (sic?) arrival - that, by the way is really its name. Mallie is reallly wonderfully well - the babe was a week old yesterday - she eats like anybody else; sits up as much as she pleases, goes all about the chamber - (walked clear round the bed when it was only three days old) says she is just as well and strong, and as able to come down stairs and be about, as ever she was, but the Dr. counselled her to keep her room a fortnight, and for the sake of being in fashion she says she is going to. The baby is a nice little plump thing, with big eyes and mouth like Maria, little feet and hands, but otherwise, looking simply and only like her own little self. Of course she is the baby, and the best baby to her father & mother. Albina"s letter tells that Josie has been quite sick - troubled with worms. Mother is afraid she gets frightened and lets Dr. Kimball administer too much Calomel. Is'nt it hard that we cannot divide Mother into as many Mothers as there are children - I suppose Albina feels badly not to have her there now Charles is away; and I am sure I don't know what we could have done here without her. She had a very ill turn herself, a few nights since, from which she has not yet entirely recovered. We fear she got too tired, but she says she ate an unripe apple that hurt her - She was taken about bed-time in severe pains, and
written up along the left side:
It is Sabbath night - we really think Percie seems a little better - has a more natural look in his face, and discharge a little more natural & not so frequent

as they have been - Won't Dr. Mc. crow if he does cure him & wont we be glad & thankful?

Lucy Sept. 5, 54 Bangor
within two hours had twelve profuse, watery, odorless discharges - was so cold that with four or five hot flats, a jug of water and hot flannels, it was a long time before she got warm. Eliab gave her salts and water, which she thinks relieved her before the Doctor's medicine got here. Percie was rattled (?) & crying, Samuel gone for the Dr. Mrs. Bayly (Maria's nurse) with the crying wee baby, so Eliab had the whole care of Mother - he flew up & down stairs and did everything just like a wonder. Mother said when he could do nothing else he would come and kiss her. He is capital in sickness - seems to be half a woman at such times - I believe I have reason to know that all my brothers are good to care for sick folks, because thoughtful & kind.
Well what a letter full I have written - not worth sending - Rufus Crosby is fixing to go out to Illinois - starts in a few days. Samuel & I rode down to Hampden a day or two since to see about a place for James, to go to school - had a nice little confab with Mr. Tash. His sister is there, Eveline Bartlett assistant the coming term. It is not yet decided what is best for James, whether to come here or go to Hampden - we can find no opportunity for him to work for his board, and board is very high. Yet he must go to school a while before going to a trade. Charlie is coming down here as soon as E. & M. go away, which will probably be in about a month - If Mother
written up the left side:
I had a letter from unclear Conant - Sam'l has got home - talks that he shall move out next - Sister say she dont unclear about for he cant get away - Henry 2 words unclear was very sick.

Bangor Oct. 14. 1854

Dear Brothers,

        I don't seem to remember how long it is since I have written to you, but I believe I have had letters from both of you since. We have been so confused in so many respects so long, that it seems sometimes as if I have no memory left.  But how much, how much we have to be thankful for! I have felt it very much the last two or three days. Mr. Rider and Almeda came Tuesday to have a cancer taken from his lip. The operation was performed Thursday forenoon at Dr. Mc Ruen's Office, by him & Dr. Field. He was under the influence of ether, partially, but not so much as to render hm insensible. The adjusting after the cutting was done, was particularly so in this case as there was a very unusual

[left-hand side] to have such an operation as Mr. Rider has- Dea. Thomas has just been in to see him. Do both of you write to them. This is very sad for them & it is so much to be feared that is is only the "beginning of sorrows." With much love, your sister Lucy. Charles, I expect in dust & ashes of all I said about your coming home, that trouble you. Albina teases us so much to write & urge you, that I fear we waxed too warm about it.

rigidity of the muscle of his face, so that cutting out the piece, (more than half the lip, in the form of V, the point running down to the chin) it was almost impossible to bring the parts together & keep them in place. He has another spot on his cheek & one on his neck which we fear will have to be taken out soon. This will disfigure his face a good deal, more, the Dr. says, than on some people where the whole lip & chin has been taken out, because his flesh & skin will give so little. O, it is a terrible thing - a cancer, anywhere; and especially in the face. They will have to stay here a week or ten days. He can take only liquid food yet, and that lying on his back with the point of a teaspoon laid in his mouth, having a very little at a time poured into that with another spoon so it will run down his Throat. He is just as patient as can be. I have not heard an impatient sound nor
[left-hand side] Have I ever written to you that Anna bought me a beautiful silver cake basket when she was here - eleven and a half dollars.

seen an impatient motion.

  Percie is doing nicely. He eats three quarters of the time and teases for something to eat the rest of the time. You would be astonished to see him put down the bread and apple sauce, which, with milk, is his usual food. He gains flesh & strength very fast - really begins to try to go alone some. We had a dear cunning little likeness of Mayo by mail a few days since - it is worth ever so much to us. I do think 'tis worth while to have the little ones to look at when we can. I shall try sometime to get Percie's, for her. Eliab and Mallie went from here a week ago today. Katie Ely came to help set them up, they have got pretty well going now. Some good letters have been recived by us all from you brothers both, lately - I don't mind exactly about debt & credit, but write whenever I can. You say Isaac, that you trouble yourself about Nettie's & Sabra's being here so long - you both amuse & provoke me. 

[left-hand side] If you think of it and can without trouble, I wish you would pick up, now & then, here & there, any pretty & curious rocks, minerals, curiosities of any and all sorts, & bring them this way.

Lucy Oct. 14 - 181854 Bangor
I grieved and do still that circumstances were such that she could not have a more quiet time & enjoy her visit more. I know it was hard and unpleasant for her, and to feel that friends who are with you are not so happy as you would have them; from whatever cause, is not pleasant. On my part, I was extremely happy that she could be here so long, and hope & expect that she will come again when you come East next winter, when we will hope for nice cozy times together. Mallie's sister had laughed her out of name, Energine. She has about decided to call it Mary Whiting after the other sister.

  I want to write to both & each of you in particular, but can only give one for both this time. Percie is about as much trouble now as when he was sick - and I get very little time. It is evening now, and I must write to Anna tonight. Almeda wrote to Albina that she would rather her husband would be gone away five years, than

Bangor Sept. 22 - 1854

Dear Sister Nettie

                          Your nice little letter of the 12th with its loving, cordial invitation, so kindly repeated, deserved an earlier answer; but - many things, many cares have prevented. It is now evening. Percie sleeps. Mother sits near me reading "Homes of the new world," (in which we have all been much interested) Mallie and the wee one are in their chamber striving to get asleep, unsuccessfully, as it seems from sounds which greet my ears from time to time; the husband's dear are at the store, and instead of taking my sewing, which I was strongly tempted to do, I'll devote the evening, or a part of it, to chatting with dear sister Nettie, whom I love more and more every letter she writes, and more since her nice visit here: but with every rembrance of that visit come

[left-hand side and top] syllable, because she spouts up her milk so inveterately. Those pricked leaves which you sent me were very beautiful - so nice looking. Thank you much. I am am glad Isaac is such a good husband to write to you. The wives of all my brothers seem to think that they have got extraordinarily good husbands! Is'nt it queer? Truly, though, I should not think that they tho't right if they thought otherwise. Great love to all. Ever yours lovingly, Lucy.

so many regrets that I should have been so hurried and confused & tired, to say nothing of a constant weariness, and stupidity in part resulting from it, all the while you were here, so that I could not give myself up to enjoying you and making you comfortable. You must not say you enjoyed it all and was comfortable all the while, for I know that you did not have so good a time as you might, had things been different. It will always worry me, and then it was just about so when you were here before. However, we will hope for nice, quiet times the next time you come. Well all this is'nt answering your letter. In regard to going to Dunbarton, we do want to as much as you can wish to have us, and we did think some of it a while ago, but dear little Percie will not be well enough to endure the journey this fall. You have no idea how miserable he has been and still is:
[left-hand side] A few of my Cypress seeds ripened & I put them in a vase on the mantel till I found time to do them up and label

We cannot even ride out with him at all, he is so weak and so easily gets fatigued. We take him but in arms a few steps two or three times a day, but if we stay a little too long, he is so tired that it injures him for a day or two. We have to be extremely careful that he does not look too long, nor sit up too long, or stay awake too long, else his disease is aggravated. It seems to have taken a chronic form & the Dr. says it will take him a good while to get well. Besides he is so poor that he gets cold very quickly, & his little limb will feel almost like frog's flesh. We feel that he is really gaining now, but very, very slowly. I cannot tell you how very glad we should be to take him to your mountain home, but it cannot be, this fall. I don't wish you could see him, for you would feel so bad to see how the skin lies in folds on his own little & fat body. Albina & little Mary came down a week ago yesterday - Wednes. Mary was taken very suddenly sick with cholera infantum.
[left-hand side] then - when alas! Maria unwittingly filled it with flowers, pouring in water & swelling them. I saved only six & those not so good as the last ones - sorry am I!

Lucy Bangor Sept. 22, 1854
Dunbarton Sept. 29- 1854

     was very sick for a few hours, but got better so that Albina took her home today. She was a sick child this morning though, and we shall feel very anxious about her till we can hear tomorrow night. She felt as if she must get home with her. We are delighted to hear such good accounts of the little Mayo. Give him my tender love, and as many kisses as you can spare time to administer. How I want to see the little urchin! Do please send his likeness, and sometime if ever he looks like himself again, I will try to get Percie's to send you - the one we have here is not good - we were intending to change it, before he was sick. Mallie prospers finely. Energine cries some, of course, but is a pretty respectably good baby in general - is going to look like Mallie I think; they hope to get to keeping house in two or three weeks. Her sister is coming to help fix. We both send loving thanks for the pretty collar which arrived safely, in company with the tiny shoes, too tiny even for Energine, or Engine as Eliab calls her, leaving out the second

[left-hand side] Wish I had something to put in here for you in return for all the nice & pretty things you send me. I can't send a carolina 'tater can I?

Bangor Oct. 21 - 1854.

Dear Sister Nettie

                     I am blameworthy and naughty for not writing to you before: at least, to thank you for the dear, cunning little miniature, which was received some days since. We are all very much obliged. It is very perfect, we think. I wish I could send you as good a one of Percie, but I do not want to get one till he looks like himself again. He is getting along nicely now. You would be astonished and amused to see what a quantity of food he manages to dispose of in a day. I really don't dare to tell you how many slices of bread and apple sauce. He begins to put on flesh quite perceptably - begins to go alone a little but his back seems weak, and Dr. McRuen  examined it yesterday and says there is a slight curvature, but thinks he will outgrow it. You know he was so long sick & very weak, and yet unwilling to lie down much. He seems

[left-hand side and top] as much about hard times & money tight and bad failure as we do here.  Bangor has hard times, because the lumber (which is its trade you know) has not got down river yet, and will not this fall probably. The Coopers (brothers) who have been considered wealthy, failed this week, and a day after, they launched a ship, but as soon as it slid off the ways, it tipped square over on its side and sunk. It was all rigged which made it top heavy, and there was not sufficient ballast. It is very bad - will take many thousands to repair the damage. It was raised to-day.  There were more than a hundred

in a fair way now to be well. How can we be thankful enough that his dear life is spared. How I should love to see the two together now. Percie tries to say a great many words, but does not speak any very plain. When he is hungry, and I ask him what he wants, he looks at me, puts his finger in his mouth and then points, with a very significant look towards the kitchen door. He wakes early in the morning and kisses Samuel and me over and over again, rolling and rubbing his face on mine so lovingly. Don't you think the wee ones are dear comforts? I feel that I have lost ground a good deal in the matter of government by his being sick, but hope, by degrees, to get him into the right track. He is very easy to yield, and in general good to mind, but how much wisdom & loving patience it requires to direct and control a child! I suppose, too, that we know little about it as yet. Mallie gets along very nicely - they have been keeping house a whole fortnight! Her baby cries considerable and 
[left-hand side] people on board and not one drowned. Much love to your parents, & brother & sister. A great hug and a sweet kiss for the dear little Mayo. How

seems a little inclined to be croupy or asthmatic, or something of the kind. Her sister Hattie is with her yet. She some expects that both her sister will be there the coming winter: but perhaps she has written all about it. She had a pretty present this morning from the same young lady that embroidered her beautiful night cap - a dear little shirt, just so beautifully worked and worsted. Her sister is so displeased about the name she had chosen, that she has about decided to call it Mary Whiting, for her sister.

   We have had rather a trying time here since Mallie moved away. They went Saturday and the next Tuesday Mr. Rider and Almeda came to have a cancer taken from his lip. It did not heal so well as was hoped, and indeed, has not wholly healed yet. We feel very anxious lest the tumor should break out again. He will remain here under the care of Dr. McRuen until it heals, unless it refuses to do so at all. It seems better today & the Dr. feels more hopeful about it. It is a dreadful thing.

[left-hand side] I want to see him with the hard, fat cheeks which I see in his picture. Do please write soon to your loving sister Lucy. Do you hear from Anna yet?

Lucy, Bangor Oct. 21. 1854.
Dunbarton Oct. 26. 1854.

a cancer, anywhere, and especially in the face. I never realized anything about it before, though from a child it has seemed terrible to me. The operation was very painful, though he was partially under the influence of ether, for some days he could only take liquid food put carefully into his mouth as he lay on his back: now he takes solid food in the same way, cut in small strips. It would have been well, probably, by this time, but it broke away a little in the night, by some involuntary movement of the muscles, thought is was bandaged very tightly. More than half the lip was taken out, in the form of a V, and then the parts brought together. His mouth will be smaller than before, but otherwise we think will not be badly disfigured. There is another spot on his face, which we fear will have to come out sometime. O, I am so glad Maria had gone. I would have been very trying for her. Samuel & Lucy Bangor Nov. 6 1854
Ducoign Nov. 18 1854

                                                                                                                                         Bangor Nov. 6th 1854

Brother Isaac

               At the Earnest request of Lucy I find myself at my writing desk for the purpose of fasting you up in relation to our business matters, all other matters are duly chronicled by other hands. Business here has gone hard with all this season. Last winter was an Expensive one to do anything in the woods and there was more done than ever before in one season. Through May there was so much water that but little lumber was brought to Market June & July were good months for getting lumber forward and large amounts even brought into Market and sold for high prices since the last of July then has been one continuous drouth, there have been but few logs rafted from the booms and fewer still sawed and brot to Market. The result is that every body in the lumber business is in a very tight place. There have been a few failures. Richer Jewet & Co. (I.J.K. Hayward), & Paine & Blunt have stoped payment and most all others are "shivering in the wind", freights are dull and none to be had very many vessels are "hauled up" some gone unto other business and those that continue here are earning barely enough to pay their crews, you will see that this state of business affect us very

sensibly, we are selling but few goods and our collections come in slow.Out of my last winters operation I have sold but $200. worth of logs except $2000, sold to one of the Proprietors for stumpage and I have some of $2000 worth of winter before lasts operation still in the boom. We (Furber & Bradeen) are now owing P & Ron $22000. on last winter's operation, which makes them (P&R) together with other hard things to have a very hard time to pay their notes, when we (F&M) bought out P& Ron we gave our notes for 10000, the amt of their stock on 3,4,5 & 6 month, which notes they were to renew into another year if we wished ad Ron to to put in $5000. this Fall and become a Partner, we have had to pay all of our notes to P & Ron and Ron is not able to put in any of the $5000 which he agreed to do. You will see that we too must needs be in a short place, we have paid all our notes so far and by some ways though at present we can hardly tell how, hope to live through the winter. Eliab made arrangements in Boston last week to have some $3500 of our paper renewed and we may have to get some more extension or stop. There seems to be a general disposition to help one another amongst the business men when they are satisfied of good intentions in persons asking for accomodation. We have done a good business this year if we can get

through the inter and spring. we have bought as per our Invoice Book $55,000, worth of Goods and have sold $52,000. worth, our busness expenses have been, say $2000, and our present stock is probably worth from $10,000 to $12,000. You can more pretty well understand about how we get along these times. Regular Bank interest here is 12 per cent, last week I could not possibly get a draft discounting which was perfectly undoubted and had but 12 days to run, although sometimes we can get sixty days paper through the Banks. The Elsworth Bank, Bank of Hallowell and Ship Builders Bank of Rockland have recently failed which has caused quite a Panic and all the Banks have been called upon largely for spec's by a class of people who usually keep money by them for a long time which has run down their circulation very low and it is impossible for them to discount to meet the wants of Business here. Still we keep hoping and working and what the End will be we cannot tell.

The last page seems to be left, so I will fill it out though I have nothing special to do it with. I am so glad Samuel has written you particularly about their business--he has been intending to do so for long, but time, it seems as if he  and Eliab don't have any now adays except at the store. I do blame E. and talk to him for not visiting more to you brothers, but he don't love to write and consequently is not so apt to find or make opportunities. Besides going to house keeping has occupied (necessarily) his time and attention for a few weeks very much. Maria's sister Hattie went home about a fortnight ago, and now her sister Mary is here - perhaps they may both be this winter. It is undecided, as yet. They have a very nice plump little babe- no name decided on yet. Letters from Mr. Rider say he is doing nicely - lip nearly healed - Charlie came down last Saturday - the only passenger in the stage from Milo! He had a coach and four all to himself. We are having Nov. weather now, rainy,raw and windy, but the most delightful weather for three weeks past that could be. I do hope we shall have a good rain now, it is so much needed. Very much love from Sister Lucy.

Lucy. Bangor Nov 20, 1854

Five seasons, preventing the lumber from coming

Dec. 5. 1854

                                                                                          Bangor Dec 5th 1854

Dear Brother

      We have been receiving quite

a number of letters from you of late for which
we are much obliged, am full glad that you
are so soon coming home, I suppose that
Charles is now en route for down East and
will without doubt be gladly welcomed at
Milo and we shall have no doubt be greatly
satisfied at his presence.  Charlie is now
at ours house, a clever earnest boy; he much
needs direction but is easily governed if governed
easy.  Percie is growing strong and fat very
fast has more spring and elasticity than ever
before is learning to speak some few words
Charlie hauls him out of doors daily when
the weather will permit, which we conceive
to be very beneficial for him.
Lucy's health is not so good as we wish it
to be.  She has had too much care and anxiety
needs rest and the open air although cold
seems to have a bad effect upon her.
Your Mother will probably stay here this winter.
She can be more comfortable than at Milo
though & think she will wish much to be there
after Charles goes home.  The river is yet

open here but no being on foot for fear of 
ice yesterday we had a Grand Storm about
one foot of snow and to say good sleighing
we are yet alive as a business firm but 
it is very hard to raise money even on good
business paper we have a note for $1666,00 due
Jan 1/4 which we cannot yet dis counted in
this City for 12 percent interest, we telegraphed
to you the 1st  to send us what you could
spare by Charles, but the telegraph folk told
us here that it was very uncertain about its
going through, we are going to try to get
through without really failing that is without
assigning or mortgaging or being sued
but not without asking for an extension
of our principle creditors, for this we have
already asked and had granted quite
gracefully, but Mother we have to ask of
them the better will it suit us and I suppose
please them.  If could bring us any money
when you come East it would b gratefully
recd and we would try and fix it so that it
would be a safe if not a profitable investment.
Mallie and her sisters have some $2300, of Bank
stock in Hartford which they wish to sell
and let us have the money.  Eliab does not
wish to use the money but I think we will:  I can
secure them for it and know not why we should
not set it to work,

To night the learning Circle hold their
Annual Meeting at Prof Shepherds
A great time anticipated, we propose
to go and get our share of what may be
offered for entertainment.  I think I
going soon to look after our land in
farm, which is my best way to go?
Your Brother
S.W. Furber

Bangor Dec. 6 1854

Nettie, my Dear Sister

                                Your good and most welcome

letter of Nov. 27 - was duly received, together 
with "Mistress Milton", which I have enjoyed
famously.  I do not Cuxunate in that old English.
But do you know whether it is genuine, or whether
a modern "get-up", like "Margaret Smith?"
I am very curious to know.  I have always
read and heard that Milton was not happy
in his marriage - that his spouse was not
particularly amiable.  Can you enlighten
me on the subject - I never read his life.
I would dearly love to look in on your 
family group in the "big sitting room" some
of these fine evenings - possibly I might do
more than look - I might be so bold as to
pop in and take a seat with the rest.  I am 
glad to hear that Mayo's teeth are coming.  Percie
has fifteen, and his last eye tooth will be there 
soon - then I suppose he will have a rest for a

While Mayo is smarter than Percie - he don't
think of going to bed without me - he is a great
mothers boy yet, though  not exactly babyish.
I have never proposed his going to bed alone.
My chief trouble with him is, that I cannot
teach him the proprieties of life so that I dare
to put on drawers.  It is so cold he needs them.
Does Corry wear his dresses short?  With Percie's
best dress I have him wear drawers, I have
made it short.  I dare not give him apple till
his other eye tooth is through, as his bowels have
been rather irregular for a good while, though
he seems perfectly well - I wish you could see
him now-you would not know him, with his
double chin, and great red fat cheeks, covered
half the time with 'rashes'!  The only thing I envy 
you about your thanksgiving fixings is your
pumpkin pie!  I cannot remember when
I have eaten one.  We were all down to Eliab's
to dinner.  Last night we, - Samuel and
myself, Eliab, Maria and Mary - spent the evening
at Mr. Shepard's - a general meeting of
the Sewing Circle in the afternoon for Mrs. S's
