I shall suspend my judgment till I get through - have just finished "Chalmer's life." We were quite amused




benefit, and students and everybody in the evening. A very pleasant time indeed. Two students invited themselves here to tea one eve this week. I do so wish you could step in here and enjoy a day with Mother and me once in a while. We have exchanged stoves, burn coal now. I like it better in some accounts, though I did feel badly to part with the dear open wood stove. On a little stand by the west window, we have, to enliven the scene a little, a few nice flourishing plants, Primrose, Verbena, Fuschia, Geranium,  etc. O, Harrie Ely brought me a fine parcel of bulbous roots - tulips, lilies, daffeis, etc. this fall. When you were here, you gave me one day some little dark colored bean looking seeds, from Illinois, and told me the name, but I have forgotten - will you please tell it me if you recollect what I mean. I am better than when I wrote last - have to be careful - little things upset me more than they used to. We are reading ? now- have you seen it? I shall suspend my judgment till I get through - have just finished "Chalmer's life." We were quite amused

Lucy & Samuel } Bangor
Dec. 28, 1854
"        30,  "           Dunbarton
DEc. 28 the 1854 Sister Nettie. I took Lucy's letter this morning for mailing and finding it unsealed, thought I would like to say "Good Morning" to you and Corrie. I am glad for you that Isaac is so soon to come home. How much happiness there is in anticipating such events, almost enough to balance the trial of a few months seperation. I sometimes think that really good grows from these events which for the time we consider so grievous, that we can learn better how to prize dear friends in their absence than when they are even with us, that our love is strengthened by being frequently tested and put to vigorous work.

 We are anticipating a good time when you and Isaac shall be here and moreover we believe we shall realize our anticipations, shall we not? We are to have a Social Gathering of our Society at the vestry next Tuesday Evening, we think much good may be made to result from these gatherings if conducted in a right Spirit and the partition fence of Etiquette be not luged in, but in its place Christian sympathy be allowed "free course" we in this place need the social influence of such meetings more than they are needed in county towns

The Extremes of society are apt to get too fare from each other, especially those who stand on elevated positions often seem to overlook those whose position is more humble.

The bond of "Christian fellowship" does not prove to be strong enough to insure the exercise of Christian sympathy. it is sad that this is so. but it is too true to be kept out of sight, and it needs the appliances of Machinery to keep alive the spark of Love which may change to exist in our hearts.

Good By, Love to your Father and Mother

                                                                                S.W. Furber

Bangor Dec. 27 - 1854.

Dear Sister Nettie             

                 The date above almost frightens me - how soon the new year will be here! How fast the years do go by lately! If I should live to be old, I think they would seem only a rapid whirl to me/
            Thus much the date of my letter called forth, - now let me proceed to thank you for another dear letter received two days since. As, in point of time, I stand between the two, I will wish you a "Merry Christmas" and "Happy New Year" before I forget it! We had a very quiet, happy time on the 25 - Ellen gone all day, as it is a high day with the Catholics. By the way I must tell you that her parents arrived here from Ireland Christmas day. They had a very long passage, got nearly out of provisions, and for the last three weeks had nothing but oatmeal soup. as Ellen called it, once a day. They were really almost starved. I expect the poor emigrants

[left-hand side and top] sleeves this winter, that is, half way from the elbow to the wrist, open. I made his Thibet dress short & have him wear drawers when he dresses up, but he is sure to mortify me if I take him out! You ask, "How do I like Jara?" As I like the "wide, wide world," "Queechy," and many more of the same stamp - not so well as "Father Bright Hopes". Love such readings, and think is well enough, but not much, especially for young folks. On the whole, I should not rank it with the books I named.

suffer more than we have any idea of. She told me of the burial of emigrants at sea - it is very sad. You speak of doing your washing because of the difficulty of obtaining help I expect Isaac will "scour the country" when he comes, to find somebody for you - does he know that you have not had anybody all the while. It is a weariness along with the comfort, to take care of little boys like ours, is'nt it? I find it so with Percie & he is called a quiet child. I love to have you write all about Mayo. I want to keep informed just how he acts & grows & looks - we think & speak of him so often when we watch Percie at play. Mother speaks very often of his blouring round after Percie to kiss him. Do you remember? Percie kisses smack now, says "tartar" for Charlie, and tries to say almost every thing we tell him to - Why! I had almost forgotten what I intended to begin my letter with, the good news that our dear Charles is safe at home. How glad & thankful we all are, but, as you say, I suppose Albina is the gladdest. He arrived last Sat. night at three o'clock.
[left-hand side and top] Now my letter is full - scrap and all & I dare not put in but one scrap. Yet I could deliver myself of a great deal of more - however what I have written is so

Charlie did not know him at first, on account of his whispers, Charlie said. It touched Charles very much - the tears would come & keep coming. He kept close to his father & could hardly take his eyes off his face while he staid. They both went to Milo Monday morning. There was a collision on the rail road - all the passengers escaped with slight injuries, but two or three cars of hogs and cattle were demolished. Two or three cars from the back end of another train had broken away,  without the Engineer's knowledge, so he had gone on & left them standing on the track. The man who was stationed on the back car with a lantern had lost his light & was unable to make his voice heard. It seems very wonderful that there was not more injury done. Charles was standing by the stove & the first thing he knew, he was lying flat on his back. How dangerous it does seem to travel now-adays, and yet we know not where is the safest place, except that it is to abide under the shadow of the Almighty, trusting His love and care in every place, both for ourselves & for our friends. I am rejoicing for you day by day in the prospect of soon seeing Isaac.
[left-hand side] expressly sensible that it may be all you could be able to digest at once. With much love from all & kisses for Mayo. your Sister Lucy.

May it please our Heavenly Father to restore him to us unharmed.  We want very much to hear from him and from you, to know when to expect you here.  Mother wishes to know on account of making arrangements about going to Milo.  Mallie is comforting herself with the expectation of a nice visit from you, and I am anticipating a whole bunch of warm comfort with you & Isaac and little Mayo; with my good faithful Ellen to relieve me from care & fatigue, so that I can enjoy your next visit as I have done neither of the others.  You will conclude fast when Isaac comes & write us all about it, won't you?  You think Percie does not keep the room in such admirable disorder as Mayo does - I don't know.  I do not imagine he is quite so vigorous as Mayo, though he has a good many play things about - he is a very happy boy, draws his cricket about, or pushes blocks, patting about all day long, laughing loud a great deal, as he used to last winter, only he laughs more intelligently now.  He is not near so voracious as a few weeks ago.  He usually has one short nap, sometimes not any.  I made his dresses with long

I have read.  Carlyle amused me as much as any.  Anna has been having a satin cloak made here - we have just sent it by express - It's very handsome - Comes almost up to your white mantle, with the Isaac-onian fringe!  I expect her good doctor will wonder with a great admiration when he sees it!  How I want to go to Elyria & Dunbarton!  "Pears like" I must sometime - Eliab started for Boston to-night - Samuel thinks some of going to Penn. soon to look after the possessions there.  If he does, he may go to Elyria!  We laughed when we read of the thermometer having four deg. below zero at your home, last week several mornings it was from 20 to 35 deg.  Very cold all that week - now tis very mild indeed.  In one place it was said the mercury went down so low that it pulled on the nail so as to break

[left-hand side]it off & Even Maine people called that cold weather.
I do not like it so well as the two first - I will put it with "Lamplighter".  Maria liked it better than Lamplighter, did you like those works of Lamartine's which you spoke of?  I have new Gilfillan's Gallery of literary portraits, a student brought it to me.  I do like Gilfillan's writings, though they seem almost too rich in words and so abounding in imagery, I enjoy the book extremely.  I think Isaac has one volume though I have never read it.  It seems to read his review of one character as though he must have exhausted himself, and would not be able to say much as another, but there seems to be no lack so far as

Llucy, Jan 5, 1853, Bangor
Dunbarton Jan 1888?
Bangor Jan. 5 - 1853
Dear Brother Isaac?
Welcome to Dunbarton!  Suppose you will be there tomorrow night - Won't Nettie? be glad?  Are we not rejoicing already for her?  And yet, do we right?  You are not yet there, and we "know not what a day may bring forth"!  We will trust, and hope that you may be brought safely and speedily unknown all who love you.  Your Telegraphic dispatch, received tonight, made lighter two somewhat heavy hearts, at least.  This has been a hard week with the brothers - and this, so much more than they expected, too, comes very opportunely.  How soon are we to see you and Nettie? and Mayo? here?  Mr Wallace, the little Scotch student?, came in tonight to bring me the Life of the Cheyne?.  He brought before Gilfillan's Gallery of Literary Portraits - How I have enjoyed it!  Mother and I have wearied? our sides? with shaking some evenings - It seems

as if he must sometime get short of words, but truly, there is no luck yet! This Vol. is not the one you had here, which I did not read: I expect to have that next. Mother is going to write this letter. I only put in a word because I was writing tonight. William Crosby got home a day or two since - called up here the next day - his father did not recognize him for some time- called him Mr. Givin. With much love, in much haste.

                                                                                           Lucy.

Well, I wrote a bit last night, confidently expecting Mother would write a long letter, but behold! She filled out the opposite page, instead of taking a new sheet, and - has done. What shall I do? She persists in not writing, because I write. Shall I have to give it up altogether in order that you may not be quite deprived of her letters? I wish I was'nt so wordy, but there. I am just as I was made. Mother, Sam'l and myself went to hear the Hutchinsons sing one evening this week. They are very fine.

My Dear Children

Lucy says Mother is going to write this letter & indeed perhaps I ought. I am sure I want to write to you. And my heart is full, sometimes almost to bursting, (like a cag'd bird - fluttering and panting to get out but cannot) full of love to all my Dear Children.

If feelings & thoughts would only flow from my pen with the forcibly that words do from Lucy - but mine seems to be an inner life what little there is of it , or at any rate without much expression of any thing of use or benefit to any one.

  Lucy can write whatever we have to say so much easier that I will only tell you that I love you and pray for you and long to see you all here

much love to your parents

               from your Mother

Jan. 6th

  Please inform me when you will be here & when go to Milo. I have been here more than 6 months & begin to feel that I ought to go home. I want to be there or want to be with Charles. I want to be here too when you are, long to be acquainted with that precious little one & with his mother also more than I have.
  It seems to me that Charles will be less likely to enjoy life in M. than before he went away & he never was quite contented there but he needs somebody to take him by the hand and pull in order to his getting away.

Samuel, Bangor Jan 6. 1855
Dunbarton. Jan. 1855

                                                                                                                            Bangor Jan'y 6th 1855

Brother Isaac

            We Rec'd a Telegraphic dispatch from you yesterday afternoon. we were surprised that you put so much money on deposit to our order, we can probably use, what you do not for of it, to pretty good advantage in our business. Accept our sincere thanks. If we have any thing like fair success in collecting I think we shall be able to get along untill the changing of the river next Spring when vessels will be carrying money again, as you will be here so soon. I will not go into particulars in relation to our business. The following failures have taken place here within three months. Ephraim Polk for $500,000, C. Cooper & co.  for sat $100,000. John B. Foster unknown, which failures are bad. The following have suspended but will resume business. Ricker Jewett & . (I.J.K. Haywood), Bragg & Moore, Henry Reed, Paomne & Blunt, Walter Brown, Penobscot Lumbering Association, John Wigin, Dudley C. Oaks failed, and the list is growing. We have paid this week $4600, When shall we see you here? Love to Nettie

Samuel W. Furber

Bangor March 1855
Milo Mar. 1 1855

                                                                                                           Bangor Mar. 1sr 1855.

Dear Nettie

                  You were being very, very good to write me such a nice little letter so soon.. It refreshed me in body and spirit. Isaac's authoritative preachment, too was duly appreciated, and will be faithfully obeyed. What a long, slim, lonesome day was Monday! It seemed as if there was nothing to do, and a great deal of time to do it! Percie missed Mayo, I think, very much, but hardly knew what the matter was, and so kept calling "Papa" every few minutes. I put him in bed alone Monday and last night: told him I was coming out to knit. He kissed me, snuggled down into bed as good as a kitten, called "Mamma a a" a few times (not complainingly at all) and in about ten minutes was sound asleep - did just so last night. I felt greatly releived for I expected an hour's cry the first

[left-hand side and top]  - however, he is becoming very exemplary. Did not commit a single impropriety all day yesterday. Do please write often and persuade all the rest too. I want word from Mother now and then. Albina has not written for long, though perhaps 'tis my fault, as I have neglected writing to her. Very much love to all - not forgetting kisses for the little folks, a special allowance for the little Mayo. Lovingly, ever Sister Lucy.

night. He goes to sleep much sooner than when I laid down with him. I wonder now that I did not try it before. We felt very anxious about you all, as it rained a little here several times Monday, and we feared you would get quite wet. Maria fixed Tuesday morning to attend the High School examination, but it was so crowded they could not get in comfortably, so she came up here a little while. She told me about a committee of eight appointed to go about two by two and visit each family. conversing with each individual personally sending word beforehand, that every member of the family may be present. I suppose the intention is to do good, but I am of the opinion that in nine cases out of ten, more harm than good will be the result. If the members of the church would drop in; one at a time, as if they came because they felt an interest in the persons, instead of discharging their duty as members of an appointed committee, and converse generally or personally as feeling & judgment

dictated. I think it might do good. But except in some few cases where such a course would bring a person out, and oblige them to commit themselves, it seems to me it will not be productive of any special benefit. Judging from my own feelings & from what I have known of others, to do good by personal conversation on the subject of Religion, it must be done in private. Mallie & I had a great mind to lift up our voices & lend in a remonstrance.

 Please to write particularly about the state of Religion in Milo. Mrs. Harlow invites me to go to the Maternal quarterly meeting this P.M. If the horse was at home, so that Samuel could carry one, perhaps I might, but believe I shall not trust myself with Mrs. Harlow. I want to go down to Maria's tomorrow if 'tis pleasant. I sent your letter down this morning, so I may not answer it all properly. Percie has been sunning out and in from the Piazza to suit himself, for about an hour this morning. He is now rolling over & jumping about on the floor playing with "manny". Ellen is as good

as can be - she does everything she can for me without asking - when Percie goes out in the kitchen, she says "shtop now with me, Percie; Don't trouble your Mother." Leave her work to amuse him out there. The only trouble is, she is disposed to be too good in the matter of sugar & cake, I can hardly restrain her. What beautiful days! How wise little Mayo will become in regard to cows and sheep, horses & oxen, pigs & poultry, if he stays at Milo a while. What an ignoramus Percie will be beside him when he comes back. I think we shall get along nicely here, but I should be very glad to have Lizzie come as soon as Almeda is willing to spare her, which I suppose will not be till you come away. There are so many things to jump & stoop for continually, she would be a great help to me. I cannot call Ellen five times a minute you know. Samuel and I are reading French and Potiphar papers. He has been at home both evenings, except a little whole at the big Caucus last night. Potiphar is capital. Percie says "pot" about once in five minutes all day; I dare not disregard his call,  so we go over all the maneuvers, usually to no purpose

March 8th Astonishing fact! Mallie and I went to Maternal meeting yesterday. A fine time - 24 Mothers & 33 children present. Mrs. Wheelright's great double parlor crowded - had a nice chat with Mrs. Foster, Mrs. Hayward & several with whom I was before little acquainted. Saw Mrs. Hopley too. Am going

down to Maria's today though it is rather windy. She expects me, & something may "turn up" to prevent another time. Do write often. Mr. Harlow has just been in, making agonizing efforts to tell how disappointed he was to find you had gone, without going in there to her! poor man!

                                                      "by, by" - Lute

Bangor Mar. 20 -1855

Dear people, all, 

                                'Tis James' birthday is'nt it? So "occurred to my mind," as Mrs. Harlow says, while I was dating my letter. I should not write today having nothing in particular to communicate, but a bundle is going by tomorrow's stage, and I thought I might as well bring myself into notice a little! It is evening, snowing so fast, and melting almost as fast as it comes down. The letter from Isaac & Nettie to Eliaba & Maria came by Saturday's mail. Samuel thought Eliab was going to put up the fishing tackle to send Monday, but probably in his hurry preparing to go to Boston Monday, he forgot it. He went by stage to Pittsfield to take the cars. We did not expect you were going to Brownville quite so soon. I guess one letter from Maria & one from me was sent

[left-hand side and top and left side] over & above all you ought to eat yourselves. Good bye - much love from sis Lucy. You left your ink- eraser here- fearing you may want, I put it in. How is your cold Mother? Have you got the other collar Mallie sent it some days since. There are quite pretty calfskin shoes (ankle ties) to be obtained for 2/ at Wood's shoe store, because a little out of fashion- toes not quite so square as fashion says- they never should notice any difference- we have got a pr for Percie & if you wish a pr for Mayo, Nettie, And what number?

to Milo after you left there. Putnam's came yesterday. I cut the leaves (and made some bad mistakes doing it) and looked them over last night and this forenoon, so much as I had time. Little by little have finished P. Papers and French, and got into Hugh Miller's Autobiography, which, I believe I wrote you, Mr. Wallace brought. I cannot read much in the day time, because Percy wants to have a share in everything I do - and 'tis equally troublesome to write - and my eyes do not endure to read all the evening. We have all had very bad colds. Percie had a slight attack of croup Saturday night. Samuel was quite uncomfortable - to say the least - for two or three days, and Sat. and Sunday myself, almost sick. Sanuel staid at home Sat. afternoon to help take care of Percie - all finely convalescent now. Mr. Martin has been confined to the house for several days with a severe cold. Mrs. Harlow, ditto - influenza very prevalent - Mrs. Harlow, with her superior wit,  "discernment" came

in 'tother day to remind me that as we had got ten subscribers for the Mag. we were entitled to two copies, gratis - but as we did not want the work, we would take the two next dollars, sending the names without the dollars, which we 'cordingly did, sending twelve names & ten dollars. I told her I would'nt have any dollar - she has done the labor & is welcome to the profits. A man at the the door just interrupted me, wishing to sell smelts at three cts a dozen! Reasonable price, was'nt it? I had a novel call for charity yesterday - a pretty faced little girl, very meekly asked if I could give her six cts to get her ear- ring mended. I rather laughed at the idea, and she laughed too, because I did, with the prettiest imaginable simplicity. Jane is at Mr. Dresser's (a tailoring across the St. from the Babb's - she has been sick with the mumps since going there - Samuel is going to call to see her. How I pity the child. I feel very much disappointed not to hear John P. Hale Saturday eve, but should not have been able to go myself if

Lucy. Bangor. March 20, 1855
Brownville Maine March 24, 1855
Percie had been well. Samuel liked very much indeed. Theodore Parer's expected. I do hope I shall hear him. I send the two last Magazines except March - that  os at Mrs. Venal's - if it was not stormy, I would send for it. Please, Mother, gather up what you find & save them, also do not neglect to apologize to Mrs. Sewall for all delinquencies respecting her worthy spouse. I enclose a piece cut from the daily paper, thinking the sentiments of the writer may accord with your own. Why is it that when Percy hardly coughs at all in the day, just as soon as he goes to sleep, he coughs almost continually. He very rarely has a nap now - goes to sleep nicely at night - is very exemplary in the drawers department, having troubled me only once in any respect for several days. I want to see Mayo. I expect he grows wise much faster than Percie does. I imagine he and Lizzie have nice times. Is Almeda going to let her come here by and by? Now there are so many of you together, should think some of you might write oftener. Hope Isaac will get a big good trout to send to us

Bangor, Lucy May 1-1855
Milo May 26 - 1855

                                                                                                                                                             Bangor May 1st 1855

Dear Nettie
I believe most all my letters of late have been addressed to Mother, and nearly all the replies have been from you. I thank you particularly for your care and kindness in writing to me so often. In your last you spoke of the vaccination. I had heard nothing about it before. It seems strange that Isaac should be so much affected by it. I am afraid Isaac will find some day, that with all his boasted strength of constitution & power of endurance, he had better have followed some of the excellent advice which he has so freely lavished on his grateful friends. I do think he must take better care of himself or he will never enjoy a "green old age." Maryann does improve rapidly about talking - Percie goes very slowly. He

seems to think more and more of Mayo.
When I give him his tiny book, it always reminds him of Mayo, & when sitting in the large rocking chair, he will move clear to one side, & pointing to the other, say Mayo, - without my having mentioned him at all. When he has his sled, he often speaks of Mayo though Ellen stepped on one & broke it soon after you went away. He has not worn dipes at night for a fortnight, & behaves beautifully. We do want to see the little Mayo. I expect he will seem quite a man beside of P.P. I can't tell you how many times I have thought, "Well I shall not write again before they come, but then you kept not coming, so I would go at it again. Maria has as confidently expected you, every stage these three weeks, as Albina used to Charles last spring. They came up here that Sat. when I wrote you, but would only stay till Monday, and Maria never got

springs to get them. I want to be getting a little something round the house, and Samuel is always so busy, particularly in the spring, that I find I must manage to do all I can myself. Tell Mother the hop vine is doing bravely, but I can find no living signs of grape vines - and the white peony has not yet showed its head. I am fearing it will not. O, the chief object of my letter has just popped into my head; that is to tell you to make dilligent use of the currant wine Alice gave Mother for yourself. I feel a great deal better than a while go, and do not need it now, and besides Eliab got a nice large bottle of it for Maria & me the other day. So please you & Mother, and all other needers, invigorate yourselves therewith. Mr. Tebbets moved into his house last Friday.

Suppose I must call soon. A letter came for you & Isaac a few days since, enclosing a card from "Mr. & Mrs. Samuel B. Reed" - Jane A. E. Earl. We thought you would not care to have it forwarded. I have got Percie's summer dresses most all ready for him. He grows like a pig-weed.
How many little boys and girls are crying with disappointment this morning! Only think, tomorrow Percie will be two years old and his "papa" thirty-six. Another Putnam came yesterday. If I knew you would stay at Milo three months longer, would send it to you! Mallie is getting almost out of patience waiting for you. her baby is real good nowadays. She had quite a time over it, because Isaac wanted her to change Gertie's name for the reason that Mary could not speak it pleasing. I wish she had liked some other name, but she would not think of changing it now.

When you come, don't fail to bring Gen. Hodsdon's last letter. Why don't Mother write one single word in regard to her conclusions about coming to Bangor? Do urge her going to Elyria by the first suitable opportunity. Do you think I am going with you and Isaac? If you should see Anna's last letter, you would think I could not resist. Please to preserve the Overseer's letter which I sent last, and also the copies which I will send with this. I wonder what will become of the poor child.
Tell Albina that butter is only 37 1/2 cts now - has been for some days - and if she has any or can make it, it is a favorable time to sell. It is almost one o'clock - The Lobster soup is all ready & I am happy to inform you that I am prepared to make a vigorous onslaught upon the same, so soon as my liege lord shall arrive to lead the ?.

It was a huge & good animal, and I was forced to send in a large bowl full of my dinner to Mrs. Raynes as I know we should not want it all - Wish I could have handed it to you people instead. Why don't Albina write me never a bit? I want to hear how she is prospering and feeling now-a-days. Ellen has been most sick with headache for two or three days - nearly a week - she keeps about, & today has taken physic. The cargo of molasses has arrived at Searsport. It is to be gauged here, to show the customhouse people here that Furber & Metcalf will not employ ninnies when they can help it - They the Bangor officers will love a nice little bunch of money. I wonder when you are coming to Bangor! I keep hoping that Mother will come with you, but I have promised not to tease, so I won't. Good bye Lovingly Sister Lucy

a girl till yesterday. I have not seen nor heard from her since & only know that she is a yankee. I was down there one afternoon last week. There is to be a gathering at the vestry this evening for "mutual recognition and acquaintance". The present prospect is of unpleasant weather, hardly think I shall go if it is pleasant. Samuel brought home a huge lobster last night & greedy I loved it so well, and devoured so much, that it occasioned headache & other troublesome feelings - am sorely afraid that I shall not get over it enough to enjoy the lobster soup which I contemplate making for dinner! I had an application last evening to take a share with Sarah Harlow, in a sewing machine, by which a lady can with care make a shirt bosom & all in an evening, & two nice long nightgowns in less than a day. If I had as many children as Mrs. Hodgekins & had as much sewing

to do for each of them, as I do for Percie, I think I should avail myself of the opportunity. Alice Sargent came here Friday & away yesterday morning. I did my best to make her feel happy and at home, but she could'nt help making a power of excuses for coming here instead of going to the tavern. I enjoyed her visit very much. She has such a kind heart, and is withall so humorous, that one cannot but like her company. She took some roots of running rose back, & some tulip & lily bulb, and slips of my house plants. She says I can get a nice honeysuckle root from Mrs. McClinch by asking her to lay down a branch for me this year, and a barberry bush in the same way from Theoph. Sargent's. I do wish some of you would sometime speak of it, and if it is not too much trouble, I do wish some of the fraternity would tale up a piece of the old high cranberry bush on the interval, and a cinnamon rose bush to come by stage when Isaac does. It is just the right time. Also, if Charlie can get them, I want some balm of gilead buds. I have tried many

Lucy. Bangor July 2 1855
Brownville July 7. 1855

                                                                                                                                                  Bangor Jul 4. 1855

Dear Sister Nettie

            I don't know what you will all think of me because you have rec'd no letter for so long a time, but indeed it is not my fault. I wrote a lengthy epistle & delivered it to Eliab many days agone, to be sent in the bundle which I supposed he would forward immediately but according to his usual custom,  he has delayed sending it till this present, wherefore I have abstracted  me letter there from and will forward it with this, ancient though it be. I hardly know whether to direct to Milo or Brownville, though your letter of the 29 - rec'd last Saturday you spoke of going to Brownville tomorrow; yet plans are very liable to be changed and I consider it more than possible that you may

[left-hand side and top] the crazy man is moving into his new house. Lizzie has been down with Percie two or three times to see Mary. Mrs. Martin's baby weighed seven pounds. She is doing nicely. They were some disappointed not to have a son. O, tell Maria that our dear Alice Cary gets totally used up in the last number of Putnam. I think I never saw severer criticism. good bye. Lovingly Lucy.

not go for some days. You were very good to write me such a nice letter and Mallie too for her little note. You don't know how I want to hear everything about you and what you are all doing from day to day. I put the braid for your dress & Mayo's drawers into the bundle, also "Swiss Family Robinson," thinking you would read it in season to send back by Eliab, but as the bundle has not gone & then C. has inquired for the book, I have taken it out again. Ann Page has returned & has just been in this evening. She is a girl of excellent feelings, and quite intelligent too. If she was the only member of the family, I should like her pretty well! Samuel has just come home, bringing a letter from Isaac & one from Anna to you, which I will enclose.

                5 - What a fine rain, much needed in gardens, apparently. Our Isaac planted garden looks finely.

I labor there day by day, digging about tomatoes, keeping bugs from vines, watering cabbage plants, weeding back beds etc etc. besides keeping my "posey patch" in order, which is no little work. I do so love to be out and it does me a world of good. My hands are as brown as you please - as for gloves, I can "catch no mice" with them on & have altogether discarded them. A little of every kind of flower seed has come up except the Grand Flora, satin flower, & one or two unknowns, possibly they may come yet, as many kinds have but recently shown themselves. I was so sorry not to get a root of pitcher plant when at Milo, but some how or other I did not envy you a bit. Pic nics never were places of great enjoyment to me. I enjoyed the extreme felicity of hearing our friend Douglass preach last sabbath. He seemed just as much

at ease as of he had preached twenty years. His subject, the immortality of the soul. He was educated at Amherst & I should know he was an admirer of Hitchcock from his sermon, if not otherwise. As I expected, my journey did me good after I got over the fatigue of it. I hardly see how you an wish any body to come again to Milo, while the musquitoes are so cruel as you tell about. I am truly sorry for you. It is so hard in hot weather like the past few days not to be able to throw open doors & windows and enjoy the cool evening air. No I thank you! I believe I shall not adventure to go to Milo till Autumn, as least. How hard it is for the little ones! Howbeit, my mouth does water for the delicious strawberries. We are going to have an immense quantity of thimbleberries, for the number of bushes. I want Charles & Albina to have some bushes in their gardens. The beets are large enough for greens, but we have had none yet. Samul is gone to Searsport so much lately that we have no chance to cook anything  - had to throw away a piece of fresh baked beef & half a loaf of bread one day. There are ever so many buds on my prairie rose. I am going to nip of half of them. I wrote to Isaac a few days since. I felt quite tried about the bundle not going. I teased Eliab ever so much about it. Mr. Robbins,

Lucy. June 30, 1855

                                                                                                                    Bangor, June 30. 1855

Dear Brother Isaac

             I have had it in my heart to write to you most every day since you went away, but have allowed myself to neglect it, knowing that Nettie wrote very often & very particularly, & presuming that with so good a correspondent as she is, you would hardly miss my letters. She has probably written you all about little Percie's illness at Milo  & my return home sooner than I expected, so I will only say that the dear little fellow is almost well now. His diarrhea troubles him some, but I do not feel at all alarmed about it. I have got nicely rested from my journey & we are both and all prospering abundantly. Sam'l has boards sticking at Searsport and has considerable care in preparing the rafts for

floatation thither. He has been down himself once. I will probably have to go more. It is 1/2 past 9, Saturday night, Sam'l has jut come, bringing a letter from Milo, so I'll bid you good night.
Mond. morn July 2. Weary with weeding in the jardin, I sit me down to finish my letter, though from what Nettie says in her letter of Sat. night, I think it doubtful if it reaches Du Quoin, before you leave there. I do so love to work in the garden, but it is sadly wearying work. Our seeds, which you helped sow so nicely, are up and doing finely. The Cypress Vine only made its appearance a day or two since. Nasturtiums grow like pigweed, Okra looking well, vines growing, but somewhat bug-eaten, two seeds of the "martannus" came up & growing nicely, but above all the weeds, the weeds - how I do have to labor to

keep them in any sort of subjection. I have gone wholly through my garden once, iris and all, weeded, transplanted & thinned out, watering, enriching, staking up & digging about. The beet beds are partly done, by Lizzie, Ellen & myself. Mr. Moran has hoed the whole garden sticked the beans, peas, etc. and is now making a gravelled path from the back gate along t the terrace to the back door, thence to the garden & gravelling the wide middle path, as also over the drain in front of the home. O, I forgot to tell you that sixteen tomatoes are growing with vigor & rapidity under my daily tending. 

  I would write you some of Nettie's letters but she writes so often, I presume it would be nothing now. How I should have enjoyed seeing those grand old mountains with you! How little of the great world I have ever seen. Sam'l has gone to Searsport today.

We are having some extremely hot weather, making men & women melt (almost) and musquitoes and melous thrive abundantly. I imagine from all accounts that the people at Milo are woefully tormented with skeeters. Yesterday forenoon a Mr. Leo, a converter Papist, a gent of the Am. For. & Chris. Union preacher - an Irishman. In the afternoon, our favorite student, Mr. Douglass on the immortality of the soul. He was educated at Amherst & is a great admirer of Pres. Hitchcock. P.P. seems quite like himself. He teases to go out doors & "pick foway" all the time most, but the Dr. says he must only go night & mornings. I have for "Seven lamps of Architecture" & "Sunny Memories" from the Library now. Eliab seems rather lonely nowadays - comes up here once in awhile. I want to hear all about your visit at Elyria. Pleas take excellent are of yourself & come soon. In haste

                                                             Your loving sister Lucy.

S.W. Furber Bangor July 7 1855

                                                                                                                 Bangor July 7 - 1855

I.S. Metcalf Esq.

                                  We have rec'd various letters from you since you left here we are very glad to hear of your health and we are also pleased that you are going to Minnesota, expect you will give us a favorable report of that country we shall expect you to call on as many of our people then as you can possibly find time so to do and present to each our kind remembrances. Business here is very dull, very little lumber selling and that at low prices. I am sticking boards at Searsport & Hampden.  we have had abundant rains here since you left and crops are looking finely. the iron on the Penobscot & Kennebec R.R. will all be laid in a few days, so that you can return to Bangor by rail. The 4th passed very quietly here no attempt to celebrate further than to fire a salute at sunrise & sunset, ringing of the Bells, and burning a few cords of India Crackers. Eve I have just seen Moses Greenleaf who was telegraphed for an account of this wife's health she is at Bucksport very low not expected to recover. In haste  S.W. Furber

Lucy Nov. 28, '55

                                                                                                                                                Bangor Nov. 28, 1855.

Our dear Mother

                              You will of course want to hear as speedily as may be, the good news that you have another grandchild. A fine little boy at Eliab's born a 1/2 past seven last night, weighting 6 1/2 pounds, - I was there in the afternoon, came home at five o'clock. Mallie had'nt been very well all day, but felt better when I left, so I was not a little surprised to hear that it was all over this morning. She had a nice time, is very comfortable now (I have been down this P.M.) and the baby seems nice & well - nurses finely and performs all other duties, particularly since he imbibed a small quantity of "pumpkin seed tea" just

[left-hand side and top] of your big spells - has really cried for Samuel two or three times. Mayo taught Percie to play while he was here. He ? on a great deal more business than before Mayo came.  This morning he said "I want your hands to fix my Tommy, Mother." He says "Here is my train & Mayo is coming behind me with a cord of wood."

at night. Eliab is delighted with his boy Mallie is well, "self-possessed," as Mrs. H. says or rather contented & satisfied that it is as it is. Hattie did not "cry her eyes out" because it was a boy, as she threatened to do, for her eyes are still shining, bright as ever, though she did cry about it. I talked to her tonight - she said there was no danger of his taking cold, boys were a great deal tougher than girls, that she hardly ever knew a little boy to dies etc. However, she does think everything of the baby & will take excellent care of it. She says a great deal more than she means. Percie fairly jumped with joy & laughed loud when I told him about it - insists upon calling it his little "thither" (sister) Do you realize how much I want

to hear from all the dear ones who left me so alone yesterday. I have been rejoicing for you all day that the weather was so fine, but it was so very windy yester morning, that I fear the babies took cold. I imagine you all feel no little weary tonight. I do hope you will not neglect to write immediately about all your selves.  Nettie, I could pick up quite a bundle of your things & send them to you. The pink apron like Mayo's which you took for the twins hung under the bookcase, dirty, a pr of gloves on the parlor mantel, Mayo's rubbers in the slipper drawer, a pocket kerchief, a cotton dipe and a small towel, your salt cellar & cologne staid, too. and your Fowler book lay in one of the bedroom drawers. I did not know it was there. Do you want them sent any time, or shall I lay

them up for you? Have heard nothing yet from the Milo bundle - shall write by next mail. Percie sometimes says Mayo has gone to Gertie, sometimes to Minnesota sometimes to Dunbarton - says he shall take his book and go to Dunbarton "pretty soon." He was talking to Tommy this morning & among other things I hear him say "Mrs. Harlow's milk ain't dood." I have engaged milk of Mr. Jordan - he says if we will take a qt. per day, he will take pains to bring it all the time from one cow. The other milkman was unwilling to come so far. I ate my supper of bread & milk & it really tasted like milk. Do, do write & tell me all the sayings of your father & Mother about the twins, whether you have named them, what Mayo says & does, how near sick you all are and everything. Very much love to all from your loving sister and daughter

                                                                                                                                                                                                          Lucy

Percie says "my faver is done & I never can see my faver any more. He talks about all

Bangor Oct. 22 1855 
Lucy-
Milo Oct 26 1855.

                                                                                                                               Bangor Oct. 22 - 1855.

Dear Sister Nettie,

                              I greatly expected a letter from some of you Sat. but as it did not come I will pay you for it, by writing myself. Last Wednes. P.M. I was gladened by the arrival of Caroline Turner, a nice, pleasant, sensible girl of twenty five, understanding pretty well all sorts of work. She eats with us, which we prefer to have her do, as there is no baby to take care of - comes in like anybody else & sits with me when she likes; sometimes I should prefer being alone to having the company of anybody but our folks, but that is a slight matter. I hope she will have the good sense - not a feeling of inferiority - to step out when I have callers & company, for her own sake, as they and I should think so much more of her judgment if she should!

And what pleasure can it give her to be present with entire strangers, who care nothing for her, I cannot imagine. She comes to me in such a way that I can't object, either way. Enough for the present about F. Last Thursday the day after Caroline came, we, that is, Hattie, Mallie & self went shopping, or hopping as Percie has it. We got a delaine dress for you - dark brown with a lively crimson spot not and then in the figure to enliven the scene - 22 cts per yd. Said delaine is thought to be very hypocritical, as it much resembles all wool - one doz. kerchiefs at /9 each, flannel & ribbon, all of which were delivered immediately to Ann Page to be sewed, for which favor she manifested extreme gratitude, insomuch that I wished I had more for her to do. Could not find the buff calico, but have selected some cunning & small figured, dark for Mayo & Percie alike. Some bonnet ribbon

I will enclose -we think it can but suit you- is so chaste (& rich for the price, 37 1/2) can be turned either side & to crown all, is just as suitable for your mother as for yourself, and for yourself as for your Mother besides contrasting prettily with your blue inside - you see I am writing what we think about it - your opinion may essentially differ. In our peregrinations we lighted on one solitary thibet long shawl, very nice, for 10 dollars. We thought best to secure it at once for Mother, though if she likes it not, it can be exchanged when she comes. I don't see but she will have to journey in her cloak, as any shawl that would do for handsome where she got there, would be injured by journeying in it. This will be a nice article for a long time, and wonderfully cheap, we thought, as Maria's square one, just half as large, was 7 dollars. I got my black silk dress, yd wide, &1.75 per yd, best in the market on Mr. Hatch's word of

The musical convention is here this week from Tuesday till Friday. Tues. evening the great news market hall is to be dedicated - a great concert.
        William & Rufus Crosby are both sick away at Kansas. William is sick abed, How much rainy weather we have this fall. One can hardly smell out doors. Percie pines to go out & pick fowers - poor fellow there'll not be any to pick long. He sweats a good deal night & day - hair is most always wet. He looks so fat and well as everybody says, yet he is not strong & hardy. He has a deal to say about the folks at Milo - asks to go there most every day - & often asks me "How far to Milo 'tis Mother".

23rd Your nice letter received last night. I cut the drawers this morning, & am sorry to say that I find I shall need more than I expected to make over Percie's dress, so that there will

not be enough for Mayo's sleeves, besides if he wears dresses like Percie, he will need two prs before winter is gone- so I will get a quarter yard at Gunst's? like mine, which is as much like yours as need be.

                       delaine, 10 yds, 22 cts _________________2.20
                       silicier 1 1/3  yds - 12     " ________________14

                       ribbon 3 1/2 " -   37 1/2 ________________ 1.12 1/2

I imagine the flannel is hardly as good a bargain as yours, and the ribbon was hardly obtainable at all - we went into almost every shop before being able to find any - then not just like it, and at a higher price than you paid. The reason for white trimming is past as you know. Mother's shawl ten
dollars, gloves, 75 cents, & collar twenty cts.

honor, Miss Pease is coming this week Wed. & Thurs. to make it. Mr. Charles Smith formerly of Milo, came in to tea with Samuel, & is to spend the night here. Sam'l Ely does not improve much if any. I wonder that his sisters are willing to have him about the store, as his conduct, or rather lack of conduct, is so noticable. He stands sometimes from one to two hours at a time with folded arms, looking at nothing, unless told to do something. Even strangers who come in sally him. What can be done for the poor fellow? Eliab went to Boston Thurs. Has not yet returned. Father Sawyer visited at Mr. Harlow's saturday. If I had felt smart, should have gone over, so as to say I had seen & spoken with a man one hundred years old. Percie had been more irritable & nervous for three weeks past than ever in his life before. He has had a very bad cold - almost influenza, since we came from Milo, which with his inflamed teeth, has been pretty hard for him. He is just getting over both now, I think. Don't fail to persuade Mother to send me her Alapine dress, unless she decides to come long enough before you do, to give time for some fixing. I got her a pr of gloves, and a collar, because I saw one so very cheap.
